reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1:
I've crash landed on a strange island. Don't know how I survived, but I think I caught a glimpse of some strange tribal man before I lost consciousness. After I awoke I set to the business of building a shelter. Who knows how long it'll be till I'm rescued.

Day 2: The tribals seem unfriendly. They showed up at the edge of my camp and eyed me while growling. They have clubs made out of human skulls and seem to be wearing teeth around their necks. I'm going to set up traps tonight.

Day 3: Some random skinny tribal tried to eat me! He came into my camp giggling and laughing, I had to kill him with my axe! Its the first time I've killed anyone. I dumped his body outside of camp. I don't like to look at it.

Day 4: The more healthy tribals tried to siege my camp today. Attacked me uprovoked but a few of my traps caught them. I killed the last man with a more modern axe I scavenged from a camp. They'll not catch me unprepared again. I'm not dying on this bloody island.

Day 5: After seeing that they have some kind of displays made out of human remains, I decided to do the same. It was disguisting and unthinkable but maybe now they'll realize this place is dangerous and give me some peace. Got a little hunting done too.

Day 6: I've been forced to build a wall around the perimeter. The healthier, smarter tribals seem to be warded off by my effigy but the starving ones are desperate enough to risk attacking. I'm going to fortify this place. I'm not becoming somone's lunch.

Day 7: While checking my traps outside camp I was attacked by some kind of weird tribal leader with armor made out of human arms. He and his war party were no match for my defenses. I stuck their heads outside camp. Maybe now they'll learn what will happen should they come here again.

Day 10: I've been a little too busy to write in my journal recently. I decided to take the fight to them and burned one of their camps with molotovs. A week ago, their screams would have bothered me. Now I was just relieved. Maybe now I'll be able to sleep at night.

Day 11: A huge monster with a ton of legs busted in through my outer wall. Fortunately I'd stashed away some explosives, so that made quick work of it. On closer examination this thing seems to be made out of...people. Sewn or mutated together somehow. What is happening in this place!?

Day 15: I cut off the heads of every tribal leader and put them on sticks. The sticks litter the outside of my camps. They'll regret the day they attacked my camps. I'll kill every last one of them if I have to. Even those mutant monsters will die.

Day 20: I decided to start adding legs to the effigies. It seems to complete them a little more. Even the starving tribals are wary of attacking me now. They know that death has come among them.

Day 30: I'd been so busy fighting off these tribals I didn't get a chance to hunt for days at a time. Haven't had time to write in my journal either. I'd walked into one of their camps I'd ransacked and saw an arm stick cooking on a spit. I was so hungry I took a bite. It wasn't too bad actually. I'm trying not to think about it.

Day 45: I added arms and legs pointing in different directions to each of my effigies to spell out YMCA". Nothing really else to do to pass my time here. When I was putting them up
date: I ate one of the legs. I was very hungry and none of my traps have been yielding any fruit
recommended:
but these perfectly good limbs have been sitting here all this time...

Day 62: I'm starting to like it here...All the limbs I can eat. Good sunshine by the beach. This island isn't so bad.

10/10 would decend into madness again."
hoursPlayed: October 14, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WOW!!!

Got out of the plane and ran away as quickly as I could(first time I played they attacked the plane like 3 minutes in the game) So I figured they were attracted by the crash.

Found a quiet place, I built a shelter and made a fire. Cooked a rabbit, but it started raining so I couldn't keep the fire up, so I found some berries and luckely, they were not poisenous.

Went to sleep woke up early morning and there was 3 naked guys stalking me outside, they attacked me and I ended up slaying all of them. I built one statue with their heads and legs.

Later in the morning, 3 other naked guys came near my shelter, I burned the statue and they ran away. They came back 5 minutes later with 3 more. I couldn't handle their attacks, so they kidnapped me. I woke up in a dark cave with only a lighter to show me the way. I heared a distant shouting that scared the living crap out of me and I saw about 30 passengers hanged upside down above me.

I tried to find my way out of the cave, I almost couldn't see anything and I could hear them, I know they were watching me. Then after a lot of stress and sweating, I found the exit. I was so glad to finally see the sun, then some extremelly weird texture rendering just started spawning trees, flowers and life in front of me.

Then went on a run trying to find my shelter but I was very low health. Got cold. I got jumped on by a naked girl who were on top of a tree. She took me by surprise, I shouted in real life, I saw my cat running out of the room scared of me.

Finally, I take a close look at the naked girl just before she gives me the final blow, the last comment I have before to die: '' Hey!!! I can see her tities''.

I survived 2 days.

This game has a lot of bugs, they still have a ton of work to do on this game. But if you are not the kind of person that expect a finished game when you play an early release, you know this game is going to be great. Keep supporting it, make your friends play it and this could be without a doubt the best survival game ever.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Journal Entry 1

After crash landing I have gathered all resources at the plane, walked a short distance from the crash and found a nice hill to build fire and setup camp.

Journal Entry 2

I went down to the beach and started fishing, found lots of beer bottles in the sand, I even found a tent pitched on the beach... where is everyone??

Journal Entry 3

While setting up camp I saw a group of 3 tribesmen doing a beach patrol in the area where I was fishing, I didn't engage only observed them. Its getting dark now and I know now that im not alone. I'm not sure of these tribesmen's intentions but Its starting to rain and I need to build a shelter. I'm going to the woods to collect some logs.

Journal Entry 4

While heading back with a fresh cut log I noticed multiple lit torches heading towards my camp, about 12 of them from what I counted, Indeed it appears there are many more tribesmen than I originally thought. They appear to be scanning my camp looking for survivors.

Journal Entry 5

After observing the tribesmen for 10 or so mins I approached one of the females of the pack, she stared at me in shock for about 30 seconds then screamed and ran away. She did not attack... perhaps they are a friendly people after all!

Journal Entry 6

I should have just left them alone, apparently the female ran back to get the rest of the tribe.... I was attacked and chased, I was able to kill three of them before accidentally backing up off a cliff and falling to (what I thought was my death).

Journal Entry 7

I have awoken in a cave of hanging bodies, I am badly injured from my cliff fall and only have my terribly lit Bic lighter to guide my way through the cave.... this may be my last journal entry as I am starving and going to die soon.... Thank you... Endnight games.

reviewText:

Day 19: Ok so I've killed just about everyone. I sat down an ate some berries as a reward. I don't feel so good now.

On a serious note: This is a fantastic game and the developers constantly  release patches with new content and bug fixes. I can't recommend it enough!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being a mid 20s male who doesn't really get scared of movies or other similar things, I thought this would be the perfect game. Like a grownup Minecraft, but with nice graphics. Boy was I wrong.

I'll never forget my first encounter with the cannibal tribe. I was out checking the wonderful graphics, looking for loot, setting up shelter, minding my own business when I heard that scream/laugh... I'll never forget it. I turned and saw him staring at me and for the first time in my life, I was having a miniature heart attack from a video game. I ran to my cabin but was shaking so badly that I couldn't use my mouse to direct my guy to safety. I played for a few more hours then went to bed.

That night I had nightmares about the cannibals. Waking up my wife repeatedly (10+ times) after dreaming about them. I see shadows at work and panic briefly. Never has a game affected me in such a way and I would recommend it to anyone.

10/10 would get PTSD again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My plane crashed, my son got taken by what seemed like cannibal mutants so I did what any real father would do and vowed to get revenge.
I found myself an axe.
I raided the wreckage for bottles of booze.
I raided the suitcases for scraps of cloth.
I made a stack of molotov cocktails and set out to eradicate the tribe that stole my progeny.
I found a very scenic looking spot on the beach and decided to stay the night.
The sunrise was especially pretty so I built a treehouse and decided to stay another night.
Now I am tending to herb gardens, breeding rabbits, preserving lizard meats and listening to scavenged cassette tapes.
Every now again wandering mutants come too close to my turf, so I burn them with molotov cocktails and use their body parts to create ghastly effigies on my beach.
I also use tree sap to glue their teeth to my axe. 52 mutant teeth glued to my axe means it 1 shots cannibals.
I should probably venture out and find out what happened to my firstborn, but the sunrise on this beach is just so pretty, plus I need to finish building this gazebo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has oodles of potential. Nothing more romantic than strolling down a sunset beach being chased by a bunch of naked cannibals. Makes you feel like a celebrity.

Depending on your nature I would suggest, if you are patient: You don't mind set backs,and have a good sense of humour. Get it now. It's pretty awesome even with all the flaws. Regular updates mean you're generally not stuck too long with one issue.. of course with each update you'll generally stumble upon something else to perplex you.. think of it as hurdles.. But everything looks pretty so that's okay.

If you don't enjoy being murdered by flying tables, eaten by land sharks, dislike leviatating geese, backwards rabbits and other such oddities then I suggest you wait it out till the game is more developed.


The Forest:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: Looks like the reviews that were on top that shouldn't have been are now downvoted. Thank you everyone for supporting good reviews and motivating the few that do so to continue making quality reviews!

***THIS IS A PRE-ALPHA. This review and the final game are subject to change**

Main Menu & Options
http://imgur.com/a/Dqypy

The Forest is a unique survival game that pits the player against a bunch of mutants in a forest. Chopping down trees, foraging food and staying warm are just some of the survival aspects that can be found within this game.

[4.5/5] Gameplay - For an early access game, you're spoiled for choice when it comes to building. It's interesting to note that every plane crash/new game puts you in a different location, at a different time of hour. I found pleasure in cutting down the trees in the game, as well as carving off the flesh of animals and wearing it as armour. The backpack system is pretty neat, especially how it's laid out. What's interesting is how you can get infected from having blood on your body, and needing to wash it off. I thought that was a pretty neat feature. Stealth actually works if you aren't already seen, and I've snuck up on my fair share of mutants and initiating....

[3.5/5] Combat - NO, there are no conventional guns (only a flare gun) and never will be (although bows are something that might be implemented I hope). I can see how that would ruin gameplay. Now that's out of the way, I feel as though this could be improved or at least more forgiving. It takes a considerable amount of hits to kill each one, so it's best to tackle one at a time or run if there's a group. The mutants are pretty aggressive when in close proximity, and god forbit you attack one and more will come. Whether or not this is a feature or a bug is beyond me, but in it's current state I can say it's not as fleshed out as I would have thought. In addition, blocking is not implemented, or if it is I don't know what the controls are because...

[3.5/5] Controls - Are not shown anywhere! Yeah this game doesn't hold your hand (which is great, but at the very least provide a control scheme or something!) I checked the options menu as well as the in-game survival guide for instructions but to no avail. Hopefully they do patch this into the game, and I will update the review accordingly. From what I've deduced from button mashing and relying on other games for a template, the controls are pretty accessible. In the future I wouldn't mind rebinding them however. On the forums, I hear of mouse input going awry or latency issues, but I haven't experienced any as of yet so I cannot comment on that. What I can comment on though is the...

[4.5/5] AI - Which I might say is very polished. I didn't expect much from the alpha, but everything the developers said about them was true. Sadly I haven't seen any mutants other than the naked female/male and tribes ones, no ugly mofos" as of yet (probably due to a distinct fear of delving into these caverns). They travel in pairs
recommended: climb trees (which freaked the ♥♥♥♥ out of me at first
hoursPlayed: pardon my French). If you get close

What does fail to bring me to more of a heightened experience is the lack of ability to toggle/remove the HUD. I wanted to be able to feel like it was first person

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHow many people have you seen in the review section with 100 hours? That's right. But I'm not just going to be one of those people who just says, Yeah
recommended:
hinting at their 10000 hours. Before I go into the review, I would like to give some context. So, I bought this game around v0.03, and I spent a lot of time just base building, not really caving 'cause I be a wus. Finally, a while later, I saw the game was at v0.29. That was when I added 80 hours to my game time.I know the location of every useful item, I have gotten down into the sinkhole, found and alternate route to the katana, ect. I have enjoyed every last bit. I'm a bit bored, and waiting till v0.31 to see what it brings, but for know, I will just review.

Pros
-Can run on a potato, but expect some VERY scaled down resouldtion. I mean like 520x420. But that is an extreme.
-Can be very smexy, at 1080p with ultra settings, it is truely gorgeous, but you need a supercomputer.
-The building system is very flexable. There is very little snapping, and that is somehing I like.
-I know it was added forever ago, but multiplayer was probaly the most beneficial thing to this game. Ever.
-It's fifteen f*cking dollars! FOR ALL OF THIS!?
-Still in alpha stages, so more could be added. (Though I have played more hours of this than there are hours of Dishonored's campaign, so its already worth my money.)
-Great community, unless you join a game with a five-year-old who says, Your in big trouble
hoursPlayed:
and kicks you from game. That legitimately happened before I wrote this review. Srsly. Give me a reason.
-Multitude of collectable items.
-Interesting lore, or so I think. There is no wiki page, so you have to explore and find all the burial sites and photos to figure it out yourself. I could be way wrong. Look at the end of this review for my personal opnion on the story.
-Devs are fantabulous. Thats not a word.

Cons
-It is in alpha, so there is more to be desired.
-When running The Forest on PotatOS 6.7 [Like that pun :3= ?] and you have it in low res mode, it is so pixelated, my friend thought that a tennis ball was a lemon, and proudly proclaimed, This is my lemon!"
-Feels a but empty once you have gotten to the sinkhole. So don't rush to get in there.
-The inventory system is set up so you can carry a certain amount of a certain item. It is always the same. The katana goes to the upper-left

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: This game is intense and rewarding for smart playstyle, even in Alpha. Great Dev support as well.

======

I woke in a broken plane, only to scavange what was left because I was hungry and hurt. Popped a few pills and jumped out of the plane's hull before seeing scattered suitcases everywhere. Each one of them seemed locked, but my trusty axe I found made quick work of them. Found tennis balls in a few, didn't know Roger Federer was onboard. Must of been in first class.

Being the Natural hunter I was, I beat Lizards and a few bunnies to death with a makeshift club I wrapped in cloth. Skinned them and saved their meat for later. Slapping the freshly carved Lizard's skin on like armor as a sick man I am, I continued to kill its bretheren until I was covered with their protective armor. I dipped myself in a fresh found pool of water near a large tree I couldn't cut. Oddly, I found a makeshift spear inside. Mine. Totally took that ♥♥♥♥. And then I was met with a shriek off in the distance. Wolfs? Cyotes? Roise O'Donald? Either way, I was scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as night started to fall.

Fast forward a day, after finding a large cliff side with one walkway from behind me for anything to sneak up, so I decide to build a defensive wall to close it off. I take to the nearby forest with a newly made log sled to transport trees back to my new base. A fire pit and Hunters shelter is made. I stow away rocks and sticks I have in excess there incase I need to build anything else. I light up the fire pit and cook a bunny on it, eating it before I huddled up in my shelter for the night.

I woke in the night, only to be met with two sets of beady eyes glistening across my fire pit in the darkness. I pull my axe out in hand, hearing them hiss. Humans? They looked the part, but said nothing to me. One cries out as it dashes for me, I raise the axe and block his advance. I chop the axe into this crazed man, beating him back a few times until he fell to the ground. His friend hissed at me and ran on all fours away into the woods. What the ♥♥♥♥ did I just kill, Smeagol?

Fast forward about three more days, I have my rear and front defensive walls built out from the steep cliff side to the oceans waters, only one way in. Its safter to light fires at night now and sleep, since the locals seem afraid of this place. I set out on foot, spear in hand and covered in mud and deer hides to keep me warm. I had to find their village. After evading a few patrols of the locals, I stumbled into three huts and what looks like to be a large den. Looking into said den after ghosting around the town to make sure no one is there, I enter to only find a noose to greet me. And another man hanging. I cut the rope to use to my gains. I quickly pull a stick together with cloth and rope to make me a shortbow. And all those ♥♥♥♥ing feathers, now into arrows. Seriously, I had about two hundred of them. Making a few I test fire the bow. We're good to go. The srieks come back in the distance, I bolt back home.

Day... I don't even know. Sun has come and gone so many times now. Traps lingering in the forest just ouside. Effigies planted about fifty yards out from the front of my gates, only to be mimicked the same way by the locals across the way. They want to show their territory. I disobey. Covered in my lizard armor and deer pelts, I stalk upon a patrol not far from my home. I wait until two break off from the group, while I keep my watchful eye on them from the hilltop bushes. Bow in my hand. The two stop near a pool. I pull tension on my bows string, lining up a shot. Release. Arrow pegs the local in the head and drops. His friend panics, only to be met with me, silently springing from the bushes with spear. His limp body drops into the pool of water. I make effigies of their corpses.

War rages on and I begin hunting at night. Traps litter segments around the forest closest to my home. I draw them out of hiding with a simple fire. I wait. I watch. They come. Throwing a rock their way grabs their attention, turning towards me. I shoot a arrow at the leader of this five man pack. All hell breaks loose. I slink my way down hill side in the darkness, as they follow close behind. I slip past two traps. One of the locals gets hung up in my noose trap, as two more grouped together and get impaled on my spike trap. Leader and croney is left. I peg the leader two more times with arrows until he drops. Small one begins to run. I draw my bow, having a clear shot. I don't take the shot. I let him run. Let him tell the others that I will not be hunted so easily.

In this forest, you either die as the hunted, or you live long enough to see yourself become the hunter.

10/10 - Would Crash Again.

---------------------------------------

(( Serious number: 9/10 )) Game is in /alpha/ and already this intense. I was thinking 8.5/10, but for the $15 I spent on it? And its only getting better every day with constant updates and helpful feedback from the devs? No. It deserves the 9. And it can only really go up from there. Cannot wait to see final product and additions made.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is seriously a real gem. Now, I don't usually like horror games/films/anything scary because I get minor heart attacks if someone as much as speaks or claps suddenly. That being said, my husband bought this game and I watched him play it. I was scared to death, but the more I watched the more I just couldn't keep my fingers off of it!

But to the point. Here are some pros and cons, but keep in mind that it is an alpha game.

Pros:
- Stunning graphics and environment. I was absolutely blown away, and I still am.
- Very real environment with wildlife offering food and crafting materials, nice weather and sound effects and more.
- The cannibals are an amazing and unique enemy. A breath of fresh air from zombies (which I am not very fond of). They are clever and tactical as well as primitive, and I am completely terrified of them! They have very smooth, elegant and agile movements, and they can be very sneaky. Watch your back while chopping wood for your constructions!
- While the environment is beautiful, you constantly feel tense and threatened by your sorroundings, whether it's movement in the distance, a shadow, a rustling of leaves or other sounds.
- The crafting system is lovely. You can spend a lot of time creating a nice base, and the crafting possibilities are ever improving with new content being added. Custom building can be slightly buggy, but I'm sure they will fix it and add to it.
- The game has a creative mode. I've seen a few people requesting this, probably not knowing that it already exists. At the start screen, simply type veganmode" and you will not see any cannibals at all. This allows you to just enjoy yourself in peace if you feel like surviving and building. You may also type "vegetarianmode"
date: if you wish for the cannibals to only be out at night
recommended:
giving you a breathing space during the day. This is very lovely.
- The co-op version is a bunch of fun. It's a great experience to share with your friends - although you must beware that the co-op version is currently very buggy and laggy.
- Last but not least it really feels like the developers want to make this a top notch game for the final release. They regularly fix bugs while also adding new content like crafting and new places to explore.

Cons:
- I mentioned the co-op in pros
hoursPlayed: but as I also briefly said

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day One:
Plane went down in the middle of a forest on a remote island. There were only three survivors: Myself, Anthony, and Josh. We gathered what supplies we could from the wreckage; food, cans, circuit boards, and a nifty axe. After grabbing everything we could carry, we made for the coast. I don't know what direction we went. Eventually we found ourselves on the beach. It started raining and we were all freezing. It was miserable. Night came, we huddled close together against a rocky outcropping, munching on snacks and downing sodas. We weren't the smarted when it came to nutrition.

Day Two:
The sun came up and warmed our bodies, it was the best feeling in the world! We discovered that we were actually quite good at chopping down trees with our tiny little axes. And the trees conveniently turned themselves into logs once chopped down. We had to chase them, as they tried to roll away very quickly. Even so, we discovered that we could carry TWO giant logs at a time! We put the Mountain from Game of Thrones to shame! And we also discovered that the plane crash gave us wonderful construction skills. We had a large cabin built fit for a ski resort in no time at all. And the most wonderful gift of all: FIRE!

Day Three:
Found berry bushes, good thing too, our food supplies are dwindling. NOTE: DISCOVERED THAT SAID BERRIES MADE US VOMIT UNCONTROLLABLY AND DID NOT MAKE US FEEL ANY BETTER. We set about looking for more food and fresh water sources. Anthony found a lizard and roasted that sucker over a fire. Tasted terrible but filled us up wonderfully. Josh spent an hour chasing a rabbit, ended up getting lost and we had to go searching. We found him hiding in a hole and screaming that we weren't alone on this island. Anthony and I just figured he was losing his damn mind. We eventually calmed him down and got him back to camp and had some more lizard meat. Still no fresh water though, still living off of sodas. We ended up building a large bonfire with logs and sticks but ultimately failed at lighting it. Oh well...

Day Four:
Early morning I awoke to find that Anthony was gone. Josh and I gathered a few things and went out searching. It felt like hours before his screams echoed through the forest. We rushed to the source but were intercepted by Anthony breaking through the brush like a mad man, urging us to turn around. We did, he wasn't normally one to overreact. Josh's sarcasm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off. Now do you believe me?" He had asked in a smug tone. I was still skeptical. Anthony was shook up bad
date: claiming he was abducted and taken to a cave full of half eaten humans and full of weird mutated cannibals. Whatever
recommended:
these two are going nuts. I need to start planning on ways to get rid of them...

Day Five:
I was wrong! I WAS SO WRONG!!! These ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s came from the trees by the dozens! I had a bow with some arrouws but the damn thing was difficult to aim! I used up what I had and switched to my axe. That worked much better. These things are fast though! Josh ended up lobbing Molotovs at them and Anthony smacked them with a skull club he had made. We drove them off but suffered some nasty wounds. They'll be back
hoursPlayed:
and next time we will be ready...

Day Six:
We weren't ready

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game to anyone who can tolerate nudity and gore. This can be just a survival game as you can turn the cannibals off on the main menu, but to me the cannibals are the meat and potatoes of this game and I find myself sorely missing them should they not come visit me a couple of times a day.

The AI in this game is honestly the best I’ve encountered. The game now features different types of cannibals with tribes that will fight if you watch silently, but will mostly unite in their hatred of the guy deforesting their land, (you). The cannibals will still throw a couple of punches at each other if there’s enough of them around however. There are starving cannibals who will try to stalk you to find out where you live and try to scavenge off any kills you make, scouts for larger tribes who will often simply run away to alert others of your locations, hunting parties (though I’m pretty sure they’re only hunting you), and cannibals just trying to live out their lives in peace that you can finding sleeping in camps or caves. Cannibals will duck and roll to evade attacks, climb trees to escape, light tennis balls on fire and throw them at you, wreck your base if you’re not careful, but they’ll also do things like drop effigies which you can catch them praying at if left uninterrupted, they’ll drag their wounded out of battle if they can, and will run off to retrieve others if you let them escape.

Beyond the normal humanoid cannibals there are mutants who can always be found in caves, but will surface more frequently the more you ♥♥♥♥ the cannibals off. These (with the exception of the babies) are significantly tougher to kill and do a lot more damage. If they come near your base they mean business and while the spider mutant takes a couple of hits to tear anything down, I’ve seen armsy rip a tree OUT OF THE GROUND and slam it into my base, destroying multiple defensive spikes and walls allowing the small army of ten or so he brought with him entrance into the base. The sumo dude doesn’t even need to do anything super special to wreak havoc, if he runs at your base everything in his path will be destroyed until he stops running.

How the cannibals interact with you is highly determined by your playstyle, though I don’t think they’d ever be friendly with you. If you escape the plane crash quickly before they find you and are not stalked, you can have the opportunity to build a base without their knowledge if you pick a private enough location not on one of their common routes, and they generally won’t find it unless you are followed home. If in contrast you do everything you can to ♥♥♥♥ them off (mass cannibal killings, mutant killings, effigy destruction and creation, burning their bodies in front of them), they will be significantly more inclined to bother you constantly. In my current single player game I see at least 4-6 spider mutants a day somewhat near my base, 1-2 armsies, and the sumo dudes have only just started coming out so luckily it’s been one at a time. Even though I am absolutely plagued by mutants, I can always ghost them and move to a different part of the map. You’re in control of how much you see them, which really makes the game AI feel more real and dynamic.
Multiplayer is significantly less “scary” but if you wanted to build massive bases it’s SOOOOOOOO much faster. It’s a lot of fun playing with friends and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mutants off but there is some charm lost from having others about in the forest with you. In single player the fear comes from the cannibals coming out of nowhere and overwhelming you, which really doesn’t happen in multiplayer. Sure when you’re in the caves they’ll still drop from the ceiling but when it’s two against three your odds are a lot better and you know it, diluting the terror.

I know this “review” was all over the place but the game is definitely worth full price. I mostly just wanted to mention stuff that combats all the people saying they’ve never seen the mutants do much. It has the best music and you get a nice sense of accomplishment having to collect each cassette individually.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basically starts out like the show Lost.  Plane goes down, nobody has seatbelts on because they live dangerous.  Plane snaps in half, but you're such a badass you are the only survivor and you're doing pretty damn well.  A blue electric guy comes and takes the kid next to you while you stare at him, but you stay silent, because Social Darwinism is life and you are going to amount to more than that child would have.  You wonder around hopeless and ravage through people's luggage because when sh** happens, common sense goes out the window.  You run aimlessly with an axe and kill a few monitor lizards because wherever you are, they are abundant.  Soon after, a little bronze person appears and stares at you, naturally you're instinct in unrealistic situations is to kill him.  He hits ya once or twice and you are knocked out because you just 'cant even'.  You wake up in a cave in which an Octo-lizard is giving birth and the babies kill you. Days survived: 0
10/10 overall.  Would absolutely recommend to everyone

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game starts out normal...plane crash, naked guy steals your son, then you are in the woods. But after reading some of the reviews I noticed my playthrough was much different than everyone elses.

I started by drinking bottle of...something. Then I noticed it was beer.

Walked outside and immediately started to chase a rabbit for food. Ran away.

Saw naked woman on beach watching the ocean, thought it was cute, turned around, and another naked woman appears.

She pounced on my face and I killed her with my little boy axe. Focused attention on gathering twigs and leaves for a fire and shelter.

Night approached and I had a fire and a little shelter on a tiny hill by the beach with a good view of the forest. Started to cook food and build the fire up when a patrol of naked dudes started to walk pass my camp. I crouched, and they walked passed. Shortly after a stray naked dude was walking towards my camp, he liked my fire.

As he got closer I noticed flashes of lights coming from the woods and saw a group of naked gangsters running towards my camp, but instead they gang-banged the ♥♥♥♥ out of the stray naked dude and ate him. I watched in awe until they spotted me and smacked me upside the head with a rock.

Woke up in a cave and saw a man sleeping while standing up. Sneaked up behind him with a rock and he instantly turned around and sucker punched me in the dome piece.

DAYS SURVIVED = ZERO

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Paranoid Lumberjack Simulator 2015:

That being said, I only really recommend this game to be played in co-op. The game gets rather bland for me in single-player mode, and it's all ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles until you or your friend gets their ♥♥♥ whooped by some naked guy with a club.

I also don't recommend this game for the easily frustrated. When you die, you lose most of your items, and all of that hard work you did gathering and crafting materials are flushed down the drain (like your dreams). And please, don't come in expecting your character to have the strength and endurance of Batman. Because he'll die. Very many times. And his hunger (and hydration) bar depletes faster than that of a Sim.

It's not your average hack-and-slash-everything-to-survive game, either. The Forest has implemented impressive and dynamic AI. The cannibals (the primary antagonists) have emotions, morals, religions, etc., and they come from different families and tribes. How one tribe of cannibals react to you will vary from another tribe; some will avoid you out of fear, some will come after you out of anger (for killing members). They change their patterns to accommodate you, and they utilize different strategies and members of their tribe to take you down. It all depends on how you choose to interact with the environment and the AI you encounter.

If you're looking for a decent, somewhat stressful survival game without the massive multiplayer feel of Day-Z and Rust, The Forest is for you. The game manages to keep you on your toes without it ever feeling too safe or too easy.

Arrive in the forest. Thrive in the forest. Survive the forest.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: The plane has crashed and my son has been taken from me. Finding my son is my number one priority but I am shaken up. Just what was that who took him? I take a few moments to collect myself and gather what I can from the plane. I then walk out of the plane only to find what once belonged to my fellow tennis players. All of their suitcases, all over the ground. I take what I can and leave the crash site. I notice night is approaching. I find a small cliff and set up a small shelter with a campfire. Before I get ready to sleep I hear something out in the Forest. Like . . . moment, lots of it. I keep one eye opened while I sleep tonight.

Day 2: Morning is here and I am hungry. Outside my camp I found bushes with many berries that I can sustain myself with. After finishing these berries I am ready to start looking for my son. I don't know what is waiting for me out there but for his sake I will be brave. I spend the entire day searching. Hours of searching and nothing. I notice night is approaching and run to my camp. I feel as if I am being followed and do not want to be out here at night. Night is here and I just made it back to my camp. But . . . this night is different. There is a full moon out tonight and I see people. They are just standing there . . . watching . . . waiting . . . They do not get close to my camp tonight but I sleep with one eye open again.

Day 3: Mere berries will not sustain me much longer. I am hungry . . . so very hungry . . . However, I cannot let something like hunger bother me. I must find my son. He must be so scared . . . so . . . alone . . . While searching for him I came across a deer in the Forest. Half mad with hunger I pulled out my hatchet, ran up to him and started swinging. I skinned the deer and wear its hide. I return to my camp with its meat and eat like a king tonight. It is good . . . so very good . . . Before I fell asleep I noticed the men in the Forest are here once again. They are getting closer to me each night.  I don't know what they want from me . . . I sleep tonight with both eyes open.

Day 4: My son . . . my son . . . it has been days now and I am starting to lose hope. I don't think he could have survived this long on his own. I have not the energy to look for him either. I am tired . . . I am cold . . . I am alone . . . I sleep tonight with both eyes closed. After only getting 2 hours of sleep I wake up in the middle of the night to find 2 men within arms reach staring at me. I slowly reach for my hatchet . . . I grab it and start swinging. A blow to the head drops one of them while the other runs off. I am covered in blood. I do not sleep any more tonight.

Day 5: My son is dead. I am sure of it. I will kill everything on this island. I spend the day preparing for what is to come. I hunt down lizards and wear their skin as armor. I drag their bodies to my camp, rip the flesh from their bones, and cook them in the fire. Night is approaching. I see about 7 people in the Forest. They are watching me . . . I do not sleep tonight . . . for I . . . am watching them . . .

Day 6: I am ready. I do not need sleep anymore. I spend the day hunting down small groups of these . . . animals . . . I drag their bodies to my base one by one. A stack of bodies lie in front of me. I start hacking away at them. The arms, the legs, the head. Everything can be used. I mount their body parts on sticks to let all know that I am not to be messed with. The smell of blood and human flesh fills the Forest and my camp. Night is approaching. I don't see anyone. I sleep on their torsos tonight.

Day 7: Hungry . . . Need food. I will hunt for food. In the Forest I find small group of men. I run in with hatchet in hand and kill them. All of them. I drag their bodies to base. Stack them up and chop them in to pieces. I cook these pieces and eat them. They are good . .. very very good .. . .

Day 8: i am alone. .. i am enraged . .i  hungryy .... . found sleeping man in tent . dragged him to base.. ate him. he was good

Day 9: son, ware r you . son. .. .must be tasty . . . s-son .. . dont enter  … .. the Forest.............

Day 10: ……


7/7 Would go crazy and eat people again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I felt I could finally write a review after almost a year hiatus to allow The Forest to develope.

Pros:
-Beautiful graphics
-Crafting system (Somewhat complex & engaging)
-Great building system
-Multiplayer/Co-op
-Great game environment (cave exploration, abandoned campsites, etc.)
-Variety of enemies
-Hunger/thirst system
-Size of game world

Cons:
-Enemies:  Mutants (cannibals) serve as the antagonists of The Forest.  They are curious, fierce, and unrelenting.  While combat is tough and fun, the occurance of the mutants I feel is too high right now.  I find now you have to hurry even more than in previous versions to establish a fortified base.  Have had to restart several games after being swarmed within the first two days.
-Multiplayer:  Another pro that is also a con.  Multiplayer has come a significant way since fall of 2014.  Back then multiplayer was practically unplayable.  Now, multiplayer adventures are fun yet there still exist syncronicity issues with host and client.  Still enjoiyable, but has some kinks to iron out.
-General Early Access bits:  Some annoying glitches and crashes still exist, and The Forest still needs to be fully optimized.

Overall, The Forest is a great game to play alone or with others.  A year ago I would not recommend The Forest, but would adivse prospective buyers to wait.  However, the game has made huge hauls and now I do recommend The Forest.

8.5/10 as of v0.28

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It tastes like chicken.  Well, after a while at least.  How long has it been dearest Margaret?  Today in the woods I found the bracelet I gave you in Nantucket.  I hope you don't mind I had to eat your arm to get it, but we'll get to that in a moment.

After the crash I searched for you everywhere and I did run into...some people.  They proved a bit of a nuisance at first, what with the dragging me through the woods and hanging me upside down in their cave.  How rude, and to think they don't even have a valet.  I'll never get the stains out of my shirt.

The first few days were indeed a bit daunting, I'll grant you that Ole Margie.  Covered in blood for one thing, and another, I awoke to find I'd spilt scotch all over my brand new knickers!  Ah well, C'est la vie non?  Anywhoo, I got out of that dreadful plane, of course after relieving it of any useful supplies, and right away found the luggage - yours and mine!  Why, I rather didn't expect to find our bags after a safe landing in Monaco, let alone here in this dreary place.

Well, Margo, you know me.  Mummy & Dad didn't pay good money for finishing school for me to be some boorish land-groper, no my dear, right off I set about to a bit of exploriing.  I'd found this trusty axe you see, ah, liberated from the chest of that lovely air waitress, what was her name again?  Oh bother, I can't recall - still the same problems with the old bean eh?

So I found this lovely handbook, and in it's pages I found the key to suriving here on this most unusual island.  As I said, the first few nights were indeed a bit terrifying, natives howling in the night, pangs of thirst and hunger gnawing at my stomach, why, one of these primatives actually screamed at me - and naked as the day they were born I tell you!  I gave them the old once over with the trusty axe and they settled right down I tell you that.

A few days later and I'd managed to build myself a small walled enclave, I fitted it proper with some traps, a firepit, Margie it was perfectly prehistoric!  I'd eaten most of the energy bars I'd found in the luggage, and gone through most of the pop.  I eyed the booze, but really thirst wasn't my biggest threat, it was the dreadfully low energy from not having had a decent meal.  That savage I, hee, well rather savaged days earlier was a bit ripe, but as I was dragging it across my compound I must have dragged part of its hand through my fire...

What a curiously delightful aroma!  Oh Margo, for a Pinot or even a nice tart Bordeaux!  Ahem, a left bank varietal of course my dear, let's not throw all civility away?  Anyway, soon after that my problems were solved!  I hummed and sang as I whacked away - a bit more loin?  Why yes, I do believe so, and is there any of that lovely kidney left?

When I finally found your bracelet dear Margaret, I was well on my way to how would you say cannibalinary greatness, so I do hope you don't mind - mixed in with some chicory and a pinch of Aloe, you could swear you were back in Hastings, missing only the bread pudding!

I must sign off now dear Margie, it's been lovely talking to your skull and thank you again for sitting so fiercely atop of this stick, it's been fantastic warding off those beastly savages!  Though in truth, the sounds in the forest get louder and closer every day, and I could swear I spotted some large misshapen thing stomping through the underbrush.

Ah well problems for another day - I hear a scream which can only mean my neighbors have come calling again!  As usual, I'll invite them, ahem, for dinner as it were.  They will decline in that awful gutteral way they do but...

I'm afraid I'll have to insist.  I'd be crazy not to.

(**Seriously perhaps the best survival game there is and I've been playing less than 24 hours.  True anxiety, realisim, fear and triumph!  And really, after a while, you can't tell it isn't Chicken...**)

GREAT JOB GUYS, 5 STARS!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My current favorite amidst the current pile of survival horror open world games.  Tons of potential, and playable with a ceiling right now in single player, but like most of this genre's early access titles, it depends where they go from here.  Seems like a great team is behind this though.

They just released multiplayer, which as you can imagine, requires a LOT of adjustment to code.  But you can easily see the potential here once its fully implemented.

For those that are considering this for multiplayer as of Jan 7th 2015:
-Players that are not the game's host cannot save their progress (each time the game is launched they will lose all inventory/upgrades)
-As the host of my multiplayer instance, I can pull an unlimited amount of logs/sticks/rocks from holders after a save.
-loot is not shared (only you can loot what you see on the ground, you cannot give food/items to another player)

And some Pros that make this game standout from the rest of the genre:

Environment:
The graphics and atmosphere are actually amazing.  The Forest is beautiful and alive during the day, and perfectly creepy and unsettling at night.

Balance:
While this is preference-based, I appreciated the balance balance between resource gathering, building, hunting, and combat.  The right mix leads to a sensation that you are not only surviving, but constantly building towards thriving.  Its setup perfectly for multiplayer assuming they work out shared items.  (We had 2 players chopping down trees, and 2 running log carts back to the base, and we felt all effecient about it!)

Potential:
My favorite review of this game is easily Bad Parent Simulator 2014" (c: Barry Scott)  At the beginning of the game
date: you hazily watch your son being taken from you by a cannibal.  The story ends there at the moment.  All it would take is one good writer to add a rediculous amount of substance to the single-player
recommended: and possibly mutliplayer as well.\n\nIn conclusion
hoursPlayed: this team has so much of the difficult aspects of the game complete.  From the graphics

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was waiting to write this as I dislike leaving reviews on unfished games, however I feel I should review this one slightly.

In a mass of survival open world crafting games it's hard to stand out.  The Forest barely does this, however there is just something about it that keeps me coming back.  Don't get me wrong here, it doesn't stand too far from most of those games, but in the key areas it does stand out on, are the area that are simply the most important.

The key point as to why I am recommending this ---> CONSTANT updates with content and bug fixes.  This is huge for an Early Access game.  It went from being a nifty OKish single player adventure game, to an amzing co-op survival open world game in a mere 6 month span.  Content constantly get's added, AI re-worked(which is interestingly impressive as is), new crafting recipes, parts of the Island reworked are all updates that come out in regular intervals.

I won't go into the game details other than that the game is actually very fun to play.  I highly recommend this title, even if you are skirmish about Early Access titles, this one is in a good, fun, playable state to try out and feel as  if you have had a full gaming experience.

I would also like to add, make sure you pick up two copies because multiplayer is a must!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest, first off, is the most stunning looking, graphically intense indie game i have ever seen, it rivals triple-A titles and even beat them, in terms of graphics, animations, and just pure gameplay. The game does its job as a survival horror game, you collect materials such as woods, leafs, stones..etc, and food and water from the remains of the crashed airplane you come from, or by hunting animals (which really feels great killing them, i know I'm a bad person) . the horror aspect of the game is no joke, filled with blood and gore, crazy humanoid primitive creatures out to kill and eat you, and the game doesn't go easy on you, if they're coming after you, you're most likely dead.

http://youtu.be/DZao0GMoRCo

The bad about the game that in the begging is really hard to survive as it doesn't give you a chance to make a good shelter for yourself, but that will probably change over time. The baseline is, the game is great and is worth the asking price and more.

Will update the review as i play more of it
So far the game plays great, and now they released the save fix, go nuts and buy this game. Just remember though, it's still early access / alpha so there will be bugs and possibily frustrating moments, if you can't hand that then don't buy it, but if you can and will be supportive and report bugs and concerns, tehn buy it.

More info here: KSalue[www.ksalue.com]

Early Access Review

It's a really engaging game you can play at your own pace. For me it's very therapeutic.
Chop some wood, gather some rocks. Mix plants to make medicine and make food. Grow seeds.

Deforest the area, kill the natives, chop op their bodies and display it with countless effigies, use their bones as a fence, use their skulls as lamps.

Really all around very calming game, would definetly reccomend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to have a pet turdle named Bob. Bob was my best friend.
We ate lizards together, killed cannibals together and survived together.
One day my hunger bar got low, and i was outta food.
I ate Bob.
RiP

Real Review
I have decided to edit this review one more time, to help you guys to decide on buying this game.

Presentation
You play as some random man whose plane crashes into some random island which just so happens to be infested with mutant cannibals. The point of this game is to just survive as long as you can in the enviornment around you. Looks really nice for a project like this, plus it was made in Unity.

Gameplay
Like I kinda stated above, the point of this game is to survive. In order for you to survive, you must craft shelters, weapons and other stuff to make it easier to live. The current amount of craftable objects may not seem like much, but they will add more over time. You will be constantly hunting for other valuable resources like food and water. You will also be defending yourself from those mutant cannibals that roam around the island. The game ends once you die. The game is still a bit glitchy but still seems pretty good.

Other
Not much else to say for this one; the sound is fine, the game has a good amount of settings. The last thing you should know about this game is that its in Early Access, the game still gets updated constantly but it may be some time until its done. I can garentee you this game will be done since the consoles have teased this game and every game that is in Early Access (that I know of) that was teased on consoles have been released at some point.

Conclusion
A very nice survival game, it may not have a lot of content at the moment but it does look very promising. Updates are released constantly but it will be just a bit more time before this game can be considered offically released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, I recommend it... BUT...

While I direct this towards you consumers  just about to spend your money on this product, it's also viable feedback for the developers. So, in short: Yes, I recommend it. BUT for the average gamer it's NOT worth picking up at it's current state. The game is in alpha and needs some serious overhauls.

Here's why:

As it is, one might wonder if the game is made by fat, lazy people. Simply because you have to eat food and drink soda every five minutes in order to have any energy to work and also, not to starve.
One could argue, with reason, how the player needing to eat more frequently than one does in real life, fits the sped up daycycle of the game. However, even if a day passes by in 15 minutes or so, the time needed to scavenge and work in order to gather resources and proviants (to set up a camp with a fire to cook food) is proportionally wrong, feels obscure and out of place.
In order for all the walking around, working and scavenging to fit the time-format, the inventory cap needs to be increased atleast threefold. There's just no reason why carrying seven sticks two hundred meters should take several in-game hours. A solution would be to slow the daycycle down at least five times, or better yet, include a slider at the 'new game' screen, where one could adjust the speed of time according to personal prefference.

Also, I wouldn't really mind those tribesmen showing up this often if it weren't for the fact that I feel completely helpless against an unarmed tribesman, despite having hit him or her three times in the head with an axe. I also wouldn't mind those tribesmen being this extremely dangerous and able to take me out easily, if it weren't for the fact that they show up way too often. Either one of these two extremes is acceptable and could be a niche game-gimmick, but the two of them at once is just terrible. Actually, I preferr none of them, but I suppose some people might, so making this customizable at a new game creation would be a great idea.

Personally, I'd appreciate if this island didn't feel like a weird place where time is warped, overpopulated by annoying, overpowered cannibals, and a place where I have to constantly eat and drink in order to be able do do anything for two minutes before the day is over and I still need five more sticks. Imagine if this game included having to take a dump aswell! Needing the bathroom every five minutes is equally realistic...

I hope this game comes with a ton of settings to personalize your own experience.
I, for one, would love if I could actually have strength and time enough to carry out a days work, then sit down by my newly lit campfire and enjoy my freshly grilled lizard before going to sleep.
And if those cannibals didn't show up to kill me this often, perhaps their enhcounters would be a bit more interresting rather than a shallow, obvious and expected, frequent and annoying nuisance, that's being a regular part of every (15 minute) day I get to keep playing.

As an additional sidenote: For some reason, the textures of skin, like the skin parts of the body (hands etc.), and the skin of the tribesmen is currently glowing. While this makes your enemies easier to spot in the dark, it also makes it a pain to carry logs and such in the dark because of glowing arms taking up half of the screen. I've tried every setting in the options menu to fix this with no luck. I've never experienced anything like this with any other game so it is most likely a bug that will be sorted out. I somehow doubt that selfillumination like this is part of the gamedesign, judging by the screenshots. Running AMD Radeon HD 7870 and the game runs smoothly otherwise.
EDIT: Check mong my uploaded screenshots to see what I'm talking about.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=331030615

I realize this might have seemed like I'm hating on this, which I'm not. I still stand by my opinions: I recommend it because it has so much potential, but only to people who really are in to these kind of games and wants to try it out anyway. Otherwise, it's a given pass untill the game is done.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has it's issues, but once they are fixed, this game will be amazing.

Quick story: You play as this guy on a plane with a child (maybe yours?) holding onto your arm. Plane crashes, some naked tribal guy takes said child, and you're on your own.

Every time you start a new game the plane will be somewhere else so you wont know where you are every time. You start off with the basics, candy, beer, a fire axe, a heart monitor (that you'll never use) and food. You'll have a survival handbook that is very useful, itll tell you what to do as well as give you a way to build things like a fire or a place to sleep, even walls to keep you safe.

When you hop off the plane (and taking the fire axe out of Stacy's face) you will either be greeted with sunshine or greeted by 3 naked people about to destroy you together.

At this point, if you're lucky, no one will bother you. If you're unlucky however, and the naked tibal people see you and run after you, good luck defending yourself with a fire axe and some snacks (oh and pills).

I love the visuals of this game, it's very beautiful. The sunshine, the darkness, all close to realistic. I love the level of darkness at night, it's just enough to hinder vision, but not enough to be annoying. The weather is pretty awesome too, the only problem I have with the weather is the rain, I got tired of this routine:
1. You are cold and wet
2. Get warm by fire
3. Rain stops, ventures out of base/camp
4. Rains again 15 seconds later making you run back to camp/base just to get warm
5. See step one

On to the enemies: I hate them. They are annoying, buggy, and overpowered at times. I would be in my camp that is surrounded by big tall walls, and suddenly *INCEPTION MUSIC BWUM*. I would look around and see no one, then suddenly a bunch of them run through the walls and runs right back out. This gets annoying, especially when they warp into your camp and hit you from below your log cabin. When you finally have the balls/girl balls to venture out of your camp/base, you see a single naked woman watching you, then walking up to you, then hits you once taking over half your health (perfect time to look at that heart monitor!!). You swing your axe at them but your attacks are SO slow that she hits you 2 times before your next swing.

Other than the things I mentioned, I love the IDEA of the enemies, they watch you, study you, instead of attacking sometimes. I love the idea of stealthing around these naked people or being stalked by them. I know it sounds weird, but these elements are not implimented well in other games, I would love this open-world survival horror game to have a moment where you hear a sound and if you're lucky, you'll see one running away.

The food: You have only a few choices on food that I've encountered: Candy bar, fish, rabbits, and plants. I hated that more often than not I'm being forced to stop everything just to eat a bunny. I have trouble getting the fish, they swim too far from where you can stand and fish from, meaning you have to stand and hope they swim close to you and not swim out into the ocean. Don't get me started on the sharks in the ocean, they spawn a safe distance, SOMETIMES, once they spawned right at the edge of the water, you can't go in without being eaten. Honestly the hunting, other than the tech issues, is amazing compaired to other games. To fish (at the moment you must find a sharp spear, can't make it yet) you get a sharp spear and go look for the ocean or a pond. You stand over the fish and stab them, making them stick to your pole. This is amazing, it's small but it's great that you don't just go up to a fish and press take". To hunt (there are only rabbits to hunt and eat at the moment) you either grab your fire axe and start running after them and swinging away
date: or you make a rabbit trap.\n\nThe building: I love the fact that you can make yourself a camp and stay safe. When you look at your survival guide

I think the best review I can give is just a recollection of what happened when i played for the first time (it was co-op)

Day 1: I built a tree house with my friend, we spent the night telling spooky stories whilst starving and freezing to death and whilst some nice tribes people were trying to tell us about the word of Jesus, since at the time or writing sleeping was impossible in co-op

Day 2: We looked at the sunrise as the Jehovahs Witness tribes people wondered off into the distance, me and my friend decided that our tree fort wasn't enough so we started work on an actual fort, We made the blueprints for it and dubbed it the FORT OF THE SOULBOUND LEG"

I then set myself on fire and died.

Conclusion: Fun game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest is currently an Early Access Survival Horror game. The core concept and execution of the game are excellent thus far. The Developers for this game are very active in the community and regularly release updates. Detailed breakdown:

What we know about the Story:

The story is in development. This means the whole Story is not there. You cannot beat" the game as is. While exploring the island you will find clues as to what happened to "Timmy" (who is assumed to be your son). Parts of his toy
recommended: cave sketches. The game has basically zero handholding and refuses to point you in any direction at all. Most people will never find all the hidden story components. If you do find them
hoursPlayed:
you will learn where "Timmy" has been taken

Gameplay:

The game is played in First Person. The core aspects of the game are survival based. Hunger
voteText: Thirst
helpfulPercent: Rest
votesHelpful: and Energy all make an appearance. You must hunt for food (or forage
votesTotal: alternatively)
votesFunny: drink water
commentsCount: and sleep. So far
column16: the survival aspects are pretty well balanced
column17: and always being improved upon.\n\nYou are going to establish a "base" or camp of sorts. Shelters
column18: fires
column19: walls
column20: traps
column21: gardens
column22: resource management
column23: and food storage all come into play here. There are quite a few creatable structures/devices already
column24: and more are going to be added. Base creation takes time. You must gather resources to build things. Many people feel this is "grindy" but I enjoy it a lot. You will find yourself collecting rocks
column25: sticks
column26: logs from trees
column27: leaves
column28: and other objects and transporting them back to your base. This takes time
column29:
but seeing your base take shape feels extremely rewarding.

Combat is a necessary part of the game. You are stuck on an island populated by cannibal tribes. Hungry cannibal tribes. There is so much to say for the AI in this game. They are already impressive and quirky and only getting better. The cannibals are currently broken into three tribes.

Starving/Skinnies.  These cannibals are very thin/lanky
column30: often naked and covered in blood. They are almost always hostile to the player and have even been seen killing and eating fellow cannibals. Often acting as scouts
column31: it is common to see solo skinnies roaming the island. When they find something of interest (deforestation
column32: foreign structures
column33: you) they will often hide and observe for a while. When satisfied
column34: they will run back to their camp and alert fellow cannibals. If they located your base
column35: expect to see patrols coming and going from now on. Skinnies are the weakest of all the cannibals
column36: but they are EXTREMELY fast and agile. It is very easy for skinnies to dodge your attacks and get behind you when in combat.\n\nCannibals. The regular cannibals look like normal humans
column38: often covered in dirt or decorations. They usually travel in groups of 2-4. They are not always hostile to the player
column39: but it's always safer to assume they are. If they know your location it's common to see them roaming around the edges of your base. they are slower than skinnies but they usually carry clubs and hit much harder. They are prone to splitting up in combat
column40: flanking and coming from behind the player.\n\nCave Cannibals. Gray skinned aliens
column41: basically. Stronger than regular cannibals but a bit slower. use the same tactics and skills as above.\n\nThe AI is so awesome. They stalk you
column43: leave effigies outside your base (body parts on sticks) to mess with you
column45: scare you. You will find yourself fearing them
column46: looking over your shoulder when doing even the simplest things. there are special varieties of mutants deep in the caves
column47: but I'll leave that for you to discover.\n\nAll in all this game is excellent. The core concept and foundation are very well done. The developers add more and more
column48: and try to stay on top of glitches and bugs. More is being added and the game is only 14.99 on Steam. 10/10 for me
column49:
I love this game and would recommend it to anyone.



EDIT:

I have been playing this Multiplayer with a buddy of mine and it's amazing. This game is 10x better with a friend. We've had so much fun and I recommend anyone who enjoys it to try it with some friends. Beware though
column50:
the difficulty is increased for multiplayer. 11/10

EDIT 2:

I feel I need to take a moment to commend the Devs on this game. For a two man team (now 15-17 man team as the dev pointed out) they put an insane amount of work into this. There is an update timer on the main menu and anytime they go past the scheduled time
column51: they always explain what happened and why. Every time they release an update there is always a hotfix for most of the new bugs the update causes within a day or two. This Dev team is literally a personification of what Early Access should be. They are such a great team and they really take the wishes of the community to heart. You will not regret the purchase

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest is an experience unlike anything else you will find. In the 40+ hours I have put into it I have yet to be bored. There is always something to do, and there is always a pack of cannibals ready to drag you into their cave and make you their play thing.

The Forest is in Alpha and there are bugs, But what you need to understand is unlike Day Z the developers for this game care about you the player and the game they are working so hard to make whole. The Devs actively take what the players say seriously and have continually given us what we want. I am not someone who actively supports Alpha / Beta releases if I have to pay for them, but The Forest deserves all the funding it can get.

If there was ever a game to back this is it.

10/10 and only getting better with each patch.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My First Day in The Forest [UPDATED]

I'm sitting on a plane next to whom I can only assume is my son. I look, to my left, out the window and see clouds. Turbulence, and now the front of the plane has come off. I look back at my son, who is now rocking back in forth in his seat. We hit the ground and my son goes limp. Shortly after, I black out.

I awaken to what I can only assume is some sort of Tribesman picking up my son, and carry him away. I play dead until he leaves. When he does, I get up and notice that I am all of a sudden very hungry, and very thirsty. Amazingly, I find trays of food that seem to be unharmed from the crash. I eat three or four trays and had some soda to wash it down. No time to mourn the loss of my son. I must survive.

I walk to the front of the remaining section of plane. I find a flight attendant with an axe stuck in her chest. I removed it like King Arthur did with Excaliber. I notice I have survival guide on me. After reading through that I begin collecting resources. While bashing luggage open, I spot a light in the near distance. Upon aroaching I see that it is another tribesman, and he is running at me.

My first reaction was to charge with my axe. After a few good hits, the tribesman retreats to a tree and begins to climb. I watch as he jumps from tree to tree, slowly getting closer. He makes it to a tree close to me and pounces down, much like a tiger. I begin frantically swinging my axe, and soon he is on the ground with no pulse. I hit just one more time, and the corpse explodes into limbs and other bits. Night is now falling, I better make shelter.

With my hunters sheltler built to survival guide standards, I make fire with leaves and sticks. With my fire lit, I notice the many animals that run and fly by, even at night. Ballsy birds begin perching atop my shelter. Wielding my axe, I slaughtered all birds who dare cross me. I look back at my fire just in time to see the cutest little bunny running through and setting himself ablaze. I watched as that furry little fireball ran away into the woods. I felt that was as good as a time, as any, to go to bed and rest up for my first full day of survival.

[UPDATE]

It is now my second day. I awaken to find three tribesman stading outside my shelter. Two with skulls on sticks as weapons. The third with a torch. Thinking that he is unarmed, I attacked the torch wielding man first. In hindsight, this was not a good idea. I was set a flame just like that furry little bunny I saw last night.

After passing out from the pain, I awaken inside of a very dark cave, with nothing but the lighter I had in my pocket when the plane crashed. I assume that the tribespeople that attacked me earlier brought me here. I look around and find a flare gun. Shortly after, I see another on of these tribespeople in this cave. I shoot him with the flare gun, and it lights up this section of the cave enough for me to see many bodies hanging above me.

I move closer to the tribesman that I had killed. I see a body on the table that looks like it has been disected, like some sort of biology project. Im begining to think that they have plans for me. I better get out of here before its too late.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ALPHA REVIEW *SUBJECT TO CHANGE AS TIME GOES ALONG*

From the looks of things, the game so far starts you off on an airplane with who appears to be your son, next thing you know hell breaks lose as the plane begins to plunge into a wooded island where he'll be grabbed by a mutant and your job now is to survive and possibly find him, alive or dead.........

*Warning* - You wil discover bugs and unfinished material since, this is an alpha game

The beginning of the game will start you off at a random crash location around a small area around the  island and where as I have found that the first thing you do is NOT want to do is to stick around the airplane because you'll never know what will come find you
You'll find so suitcases you can break down, logs and wood you can collect and other varities of items, a survival guide to build traps and shelter, cook food, create explosives, wash yourself from blood, staying warm the cold. Lots more being added.


+ Variety of cool stuff to craft, INCLUDING EXPLOSIVES!
+ Fun gameplay of trap buildings and base defense. Looks like more stuff will be added
+Graphics are looking good for an indie survival game
+Good ambience and background noises. Scary at night especially when you don't know what is making those strange sound
+Immersive and scary
+Hours of fun finding items, crafting, and building however the xploration is limited.

-Majority of the areas are closed off you can only explore a limited of space which is still large
- just some bugs that needs ironing out, optimization etc, what you expect? ITS PRE ALPHA.
- Multiplayer not available yet
- Inventory space is limited, you can only carry 2 log at a time to buildd up an 82 log cabin
- Interface for backpack could use some work.

You can check out footages on twitch/kenutty
voteText: 283 of 360 people (79%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have spent the last 4 and a half days reading through ALL of the code, and I mean all 1500+ source files from 19 compiled binaries that came with the Alpha.

While the engine, its systems and all the various functions across the entire game show that it is EXTREMELY early in the games development timeline (almost to the point you could say only-just-started). HOWEVER, and this is a really big HOWEVER, hence the caps. The different core functions that create the game (Physics, AI, Crafting, Environment, Survival, Graphics) are impressive in their construction. They have used some of the top add-ins for unity to speed up the games creation and improve the complexity of several core systems, and built on top of that base to create the alpha we are playing now. It is likely the integration of these systems so that they work together in unison is the reason for the initial release delays. Likely the graphical side.

The bits we really care about, Items, AI, Crafting, Survival Mechanics and World interaction are all setup in such a way that adding new things, improving current stuff or replacing parts entirely is easy from a coding perspective, thanks to the methods they use to pass information and trigger functions across entities in the game world.

Most of what we are experiencing in the Alpha is what I call place-holder code. Simple versions of what the function should do once it has been developed. Just enough code so that the function will not crash the game, or another function if it is called. SO MANY functions do not even have code written for them. They do nothing when or if they are even called.
Some areas are of course further developed than others. Building structures and crafting is quite fleshed out fundamentally, the AI is all ready for family based societies and most of the complex roaming and searching code is not being used. Combat is not even their really. being able to collide with things and pass functions calls allows the simplistic fighting and moving we have in the game, and I seriously think this will be replaced entirely.

My guess is that the first few patches will be stability and integration patches. These will improve the functions in the areas most reported and further integrate the different add-ins with their own code, and finally customizing those add-ins further to support the game they want to create. Further content, like additional craftables and buildables, and more complex AI (like family society) will probably not come until another patch or two has past. Depending on the assets they have ready now, and the complexity of how those are used in game, we will see a handful of craftables, items or buildings added in any patch, but big content will be later. We are likely to see movement, collision, combat and item interaction improve dramatically in the next two patches, as well as performance increases and general stability.

I also assume that the integration of these add ins, and customizing them would be quite complex and time consuming. Working with other peoples code can be time consuming and unpredictable until you are as familiar with that code as you would be your own. These add-ins are not simple little modules, they are advanced highly developed and quite complex systems. As time passes, the dev's will get more and more familiar with the coding of these, and development speed will increase.

I found no evidence (in my mind) that suggested any aspect of what they advertised was false or misleading as far as what the game is becoming. In fact the code suggests that the game is going to be a lot more than what we know already. There are some really cool things that just are not used or spoken of at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started up the game thinking it was going to be another DayZ/Rust Survival game clone/wannabe.

I was horribly horribly wrong.

1st try: Started up, stayed at the airplane, got snatched up by the enemies, died.
2nd: ran far away from the plane, accidently ran into a patrol of enemies
3rd: found the beach, Started making a hut, Patrol saw the hut and ran into it, I was sleeping.
4th: Found a beach, decided to wait and watch for patrol, found the patrol not too far away, but far enough away. Built a camp, survived a few nights while building up the camp, made some traps around the hut, expanded. Chopped down a tree without noticing a patrol nearby. They heard it, noticed the camp, ran at the camp. no one was in it, took the food in my fire and left. One stayed behind. I killed the one, next day hear a screech, ran behind a tree, watched the patrol that was there the night before race into the hut. They found their dead partner, screamed, and immedatly ran out in search of me. Fanned out running in every direction, one came across me behind a tree. I struck, he screeched and alerted his pals. I died taking down four of them.

I havent encountered even half of the game yet, in the few hours I played I got immersed, horrified of every sound, and awed at the beauty of the forest and ocean. It's a great game already. Yeah it has it's bugs and problems, but it's an alpha. the important part is it's a great game from the beggining. It can only get better from here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pants pee-ingly good, but good luck trying to get your friends to play it with you after watching the trailer (believe me, I've tried).

The thing I like most is that there's absolutely no way to avoid the monsters. I've tried swimming to the middle of the lake during the night -- it rained and my character began to get hypothermic. I tried building my shelter on an island -- I kept running out of food and fire tinder and eventually sharks began appearing in the surrounding water and the mutants were waiting for me on the shore. I tried to build my shelter on a mountain -- they got suspicious after I was picking too many blueberries.

The AI in this game is incredible. The only way I can manage to escape them is to build a new shelter made of sticks every day, but then the game loses its horror aspect and becomes a scavenging game (not a bad thing, imo).

The only downside to this game is that I'm too scared to play it normally. I've tried building a log cabin, but I got a bit chickened out after groups of 4 of them started appearing and their legs multiplied .. so there's that.

This is the only game to have scared me other than Amnesia and Exmortis, so needless to say, I am impressed :)

10/10 would press 'esc' key again
