reviewText:
Early Access Review

Your plane crashes. You wake up to see a mutant stealing your child. You decide that you must survive, but how does one survive? You follow your first instincts and kill those mutants and dismember their bodies. Sorting the limbs, heads, and torsos into separate piles and creating a ritual of sacraficing the torsos to the cliff gods. The remaining body parts are put on stakes and burned to show the other tribal islanders who's boss. You're not sure if these effigies frighten the tribals or turn them more aggresive, but you disreguard this thought and continue building your glorious meat statues. Some time passes, either hours or years, your sense of time has completely faded because your days consist of only murder, dismemberment, and cutting down trees. One day while you're speaking to yourself about how little you actually know about these mutants and hacking away at one of their necks with your axe you finally cut through it's vertebrae and the head separates from the body and somehow rockets you into the air and off a cliff, killing you instantly.

11/10
Would turn into a satanic mutant sacraficing maniac again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game should be the new standard set for survival games. The first day begins gathering basic supplies: food, water, sticks, rocks, and setting up a basic shelter. It might even seem peaceful at first. Lonely, but peaceful. Then the cannibals arrive. Its the middle of the night, you wonder why sleeping only lasted through half the night as a leader and others in the night patrol encircle your pitifully undefended camp. This is one of the few games that forces you to flee in that situation, leaving everything behind. But then a new day comes! You harvest lumber, you hunt, and you build to survive. But beware, as your impact on the forest becomes more obvious, the cannibals bully you more and more.

Truly a spectacular single player experience, and once more bugs are fixed, the same could be said for online play. The only reason this game isnt a perfect 10/10 is some annoying bugs, but it really does feel like a finished product to me, so final rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being an early access game, I picked this up since I've saw a few videos of the gameplay and it seems like something that is exiting to play in its current state, and I sure regret nothing. The gameplay is VERY immersive, GUI is rarely in your way and every point of the game it feels like you're in it. As someone who also likes horror games, this one goes high in my list for that genre, the atmosphere can be very creepy and I've spent many days huddled in my treehouse listening to the screams of cannibals in the distance. The combat is also great and there are many possible tactics you can use to suppress the cannibals. Now there are a few annoying bugs here and there but nothing very game-breaking. The graphics are also INSANELY good for a game made by such a small group of people using the unity engine, it definitely makes the game much more appealing.

Overall I'll give the game 8.5837/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game! not only is it graphicly stunning but so much attention to detail has been paid to the intricacies within the gameplay. The A.I. is great and has ironicly been the cause of some bad reviews because people simply haven't understood that the natives have so many different character traits and responses to your interaction with them. Sometimes you cause fear, sometimes intrigue, these natives don't act in a singular 'standard' manner. Your interaction with them and the habitat around you all contribute to the circumstances you will find yourself in.

Early Access can be a minefield, I know, I have supported quite a few but I would like to point out that the developers of this game are the most hard working and dedicated team I have come across in the Early Access Genre. (If you don't believe me, go and check out their changelog for the last 12 months) As soon as you boot the game it will tell you when the next update is due (on average, every 28 days) and every update consists of a massive list of changes, fixes and tweaks.

There is no good reason I can think of not to buy this game if you like the survival genre, it ticks more boxes than any other game of it's type. Even in its early access state it is fantastic!!

11/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Considering that its Alpha stage, its brilliant.

The game itself at this stage, is well worth the money.

...There are many types of animal to prey on, kill, skin and eat/used to craft, so far ive seen lizards, deer, rabbits, fish, turtles, racoons, birds, and boar... of which, can be used to craft/cook.

...With headhphones on, the game is engaging and spooky, never knowing when you might be being spied upon or spotted by the enemy, the eery noise that alerts you when you've been seen or even if they.re suspicious.... ...some of them sound like 'Lord of The Rings' Smeegle on a bad day, ...sinister giggles... footsteps in the dark... O_____O

...Sometimes the mustants/cannibals will back off and run away, but sometimes there will be a group of them (and i believe they communicate between groups with distance between them, however it may just be me making it up in my head through in game paranoia)...they will chase you, try to knock you out...to take you to their pitch black, damp and spooky cave, corpses hanging from the ceilings...       -of which you have to (try to) escape,sometimes seemingly impossible-to-navigate cave sections, with only a lighter of which to find your way out with... which occasionally goes out, only to be re lit, to sometimes come face to face withyour captors... ...and they dont give second chances once they've caught you.

The lower than expected requirements needed to run it -(considering the amount of things going on/large array of plant and animal diversity and quantity -depending on your graphical option settings-as far as plantlife is concerned), i'd assume this is down to the ability of the developers/game engine...


**CAUTION**

For your first few hours i'd caution you all that, until you are completely familiar with the workings of the game, you should have been to the toilet before you sit down to play, because-
(...and to note,  i'm not usually easily spooked)...
-there is something about 'The Forest'- that makes it stand out from others within the same genre...The fluid/ slightly tactical movements made by the mutants,cannibals and animals, with their seemingly non standard boundaries of usual survival/openworld games, alongside the noises created by animals, yourself,the enemy or background noise, the fear of being found in the first few hours...

Looking forward to future updates and (minor) bugfixes, well done to the developers.

voteText: 98 of 112 people (88%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THE MOST IMMERSIVE GAME I'VE EVER PLAYED


(multiplayer thoughts, and update comments at the bottom)

I've been gaming for over 30 years and I've never experienced anything quite as special as The Forest is.
Very quickly, you're the lone survivor of a plane crash on an unknown island and your task is to find and rescue your kidnapped son - okay, maybe the devs lied about you being the only survivor of that crash.
To do this you have to craft, build, explore, defend yourself, and survive long enough to track him down before the local cannibals figure out he's their equivalent of nice juicy veal steak. Yum yum.


PROS

Environment/Atmosphere/Mood
- Very nice graphics. The flora of the woodland - from the grass and ferns to the tallest trees, and pretty much everything in between - transports you away to a rustic, lush green island and thoroughly immerses you there.
- Truly pitch black conditions at night (apart from when the moon is out) and in caves. THIS is what Skyrim should have been. Navigating at night is difficult and very dangerous. Do you just sleep through the night or press on with your work?
- The best caves and cave exploration I've ever seen in a game. The general design for them is great, and you truly do get a sense of clautrophobia that hightens the tension of an already scary game. Some of the caves are very long too so you have to make sure you're thoroughly prepared before you dare disappear into the blackness.
- The wind blows through the forest, pushing all the leaves and bushes and creating wonderful rustling sounds all around you. You must experience it to feel how atmospheric it is!
- The distant running of underground streams and the dripping of water from the ceiling create a wonderful sense of being deep in an ancient cave. The sound effects are truly great.
- I was chasing a raccoon with a spear and it jumped up onto a tree and ran up the trunk to the top. How cool is that? I wasn't expecting that and it surprised me immensely (in a good way).
- The best inventory system in a game I've ever seen. All your items are laid out on a sheet of tarp as if you've just emptied out your rucksack onto the ground. You can then place different items in the centre area to try and combine them into new things. This is an excellent crafting system, as you have to experiment to find out what will combine to produce what.
- The cannibals make some truly disturbing noises, especially when they're asleep in the caves.


Combat
- Very satisfying first person combat with melee and ranged weapons, molotovs and even DIY explosives. Everything you could possibly need to get rid of those pesky cannibals.
- You can craft and lay traps to capture or kill the cannibals. Just place them on the ground and then sit back to enjoy the view.

Survival
- Excellent survival experience. You'll have to become very good at chasing fast rabbits if you don't want to starve to death. You'll also need to be looking out permanently for sources of fresh water - I almost died of thirst during my first in-game day. Other factors to take into consideration are the cold and succumbing to illness/infection. Although these last two still appear to be in development at the time of writing.

Gameplay
- A free building system (similar to that in Rust) that allows you to build pretty much any kind of base you'd like.
- You can build an Ewok village in the trees! :D
- A survival game with a story and end game scenario quest. Moreover, not just any story; but one you will care about and will want to work towards completing. You will want to survive, adapt, and rescue your kidnapped son.
- Lumberjacking is a strangely satisfying and soothing experience.
- The devs have meticulously hand-crafted a large island with unique places to discover (No procedural generation here!). You really will have to work to discover quite a few of the hidden things in caves and in amongst the dense foliage above ground.


Extra Info
- VERY polished for an early access title.
- Great value for money at the current asking price. I would have happily paid 2 or 3 times as much - even in its current state.
- Very stable for early access. I've experienced only a few minor issues.


CONS

- It's still only in early access stage :'(

- Objects that you can pick up (sticks and rocks for crafting) glow and flash - this truly does break the immersion. Please give us the option to turn this off!
- Combat still lags and jerks, and also freezes for a second (this seems to be most obvious when a cannibal jumps at you). This is frustrating because you lose the flow of the fight and you'll have to spin your character around desperately looking for your attacker before they hit you from some completely unsuspected angle.
- Occasionally, a cannibal will hit you and you'll go flying 100 feet into the air. The punch won't kill you, but the fall sure will.


***Multiplayer Review Update***

Personally, I prefer the forest in single player mode, as it gives you that true feeling of isolation on a hostile island. But multiplayer, with up to 8 people, is very enjoyable. It's definitely easier, as you can fight the cannibals together (3 of us took down a group of 5 of them very quickly) and building is much quicker. With extra pairs of hands you can build elaborate structures rather quickly.
There are some bugs, however, e.g. sounds and certain textures not working/triggering properly. These seem to occur when your CoOp partners are interacting with the environment and enemies. I think it must be because of some sort of lack of synchronisation between the server and players.
I've deliberately kept this part of the review short, sorry, but mulitplayer is definitely recommended. Especially if you have some good friends to run around and hack and slash with :)


***10th December 2015 UPDATE***

After this latest update your actions in the environment really seem to affect whether the cannibals can find you.
I lit a fire (just as an experiment) and then ran away to a safe distance. Sure enough, one minute later I can see an enemy running around my makeshift camp clearly searching for who or what built it.
I also started lumberjacking in a remote area - again as an experiment. Five trees later, and one stump destroyed with an explosive, and there were loads of them just flocking to where I'd been working! That put me in a lot of danger, and in the end all I could do was run away to safety, abandoning what could have been my new home.
The Forest just keeps getting better and better! :)


If you'd like to know more, especially about multiplayer, feel free to leave questions below and I'll get back to you.
If you didn't find this helpful, do let me know why - thanks :)

I don't write reviews for no good reason, so if you happen to see this, please take time to read. This my first 8 hour impression of The Forest.

I play too many survival games, its the genre of the hour these days it seems.
I have problems with survival games... I love them, but they're broken, culturally in most cases and mechanically in others.

I've owned The Forest for 6 months now and never put an ounce of time into it. I've played Rust, I've played Landmark, Ark, DayZ (modded well before all this alpha crap started). The list could contiune on for quite some time.

I'll be honest, most days I want to go back to the time when Steam asked us to vote on Steam Greenlight" and change my vote... but for The Forest this is not the case.

The Forest is well done for an alpha of nearly 6 months

- Floating ladders to treehouse.

10/10 - Would kill seagulls again

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Forest is currently not 100% completed, so it leaves a lot to be desired. There's nothing worse than playing an open world, exploration game and seeing there is an area that is not yet available. The crafting and building aspect of the game is very fun and the learning curve is very quick to figure out. The Cannibals are very realistic and diverse in the way they approach you, and each of them have their own unique way of dealing with you as well. I like the fact that when you do die, you have a chance of waking up in an underground hold, which is either lightly guarded or not at all. But your health is severely reduced along with your hunger pains, but you do keep all of your crafted weapons, medicine, food etc. I'm not sure if this is right or not, but when my health is depleted and have armor left I usually end up alive in one of the underground camps. The Calm Mode" is okay I guess for people that want to use it as a building simulator

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest is an amazing sandbox game that is in early access full of mystery and thrill and as the name says you're in a forest.
The things that i loved of this game and as others of its kind, is that you have to craft things to survive, since a small building up to a big fortress, find food / fire / water to survive another day.

But isn't all, you're not alone here:

The story begins when your plane crash and lands in an island, a naked cannibal (or a native from the forest) takes your son and you have to find him (but it's on early access and there is not campaign yet) and you have to survive and defend from the cannibals and the mutants from the forest, finding secrets about what happened in the island and weapons to survive, these are the story points.

Now the facts of the game makes it an unique experience, apart from the story:

- The craft system is small but good.
- There are only a few animals (deers, birds, boars, turtles,etc.) not much as there is in real forests.
- The 50% of the time that you spend on this game is chopping trees.
- You can make your custom buildings.
- The cannibals / mutants come from nowhere to ruin your day / buildings. You have to combat them.
- The graphics look quite amazing.
- And as this game still in Alpha version it has some bugs, but these devs works on it on coming updates quickly. Each update is full of cool things.

The Forest is one of the best open world / survival games that i have, i'm 100% sure to recommend this game for you if you want to have fun, or get some jumpscare.

Looking forward to seeing where the game goes.

If you have enjoyed this review, please consider to follow our Curator page
This review was written for : The Panda's Corner

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I REALLY like this game. It started off with many bugs, but has come a LONG way! The reasons I like this game:
1) The AI: The AI is extremely impressive. The natives apparently climb up trees (I say apparently because I have not seen it myself), have hunting parties and scouts, are creepy and it's hard to predict their next move. E.G I encountered a group of 3 natives once, and they ran around me and made some form of a triangular shape around me. I went forward to one of them who backed away. Then I turned to another one who dashed forward, and instead of attacking me like I thought they would, they stopped closer to me, where I then attacked them. This time one of the others came at me from behind and the other made a load roar/shrieking sound alerting their friends of my presence. The hit from behind stunned my character and I was brought down by the natives.
2) The Atmosphere: The game produces an eerie atmosphere, especially at night. When I hear a native laughing or screaming it sends me running to my base, or hiding from them wherever I can. Even when there are no natives around, I'm still at the ready, as I never know when I might come across a native hunting party.
3) The Graphics: For an indie game the graphics are amazing! The light coming through the leaves is a nice touch. The graphics are stunning for an indie game. End of.
4) The Gameplay: Now the most important part of the game. The gameplay. I do like good graphics but when there's good gameplay ,good graphics aren't NEEDED (THIS DOES NOT MEAN EITHER OR. I LIKE BOTH TOGETHER!). The game is a great mix of horror and survival, not making it like a horror game where you find a few cool items and nothing else, but at the same time not making it like a hardcore survival game with some enemies, hardly capable of stopping you. It balances the two just right. It is best to gather resources to build a base, and then look for resources to make more tools to aid my fight against the natives. There are still a few unique tools, that cannot be crafted, but I won't say what they are because you might  want to find out for yourself and get a great feeling when you find them. The natives are powerful, creepy and terrifying. Now scores!
The AI: I think they are a great enemy to have in the game, and this is in an alpha build! Some little glitches but overall they're great. 9.5/10
The Atmosphere: It's eerie and suits the game perfectly! I like a good atmosphere in a game, and The Forest really deserves a mention for the atmosphere it creates. Obviously co-op is a little less scary, but they can probably find a way to make it a creepy a singleplayer. 9/10
The Graphics: The graphics are brilliant for an indie game, but there is room for some improvement. Also playermodels are limited but who really cares what you look like in a game? 8.5/10
The Gameplay: The atmosphere and the gameplay work very well together. Obviously some room for improvement. 9/10
Overall: I've had so much fun playing The Forest. I will have a lot more fun playing The Forest. The game is a great game overall. It has many elements to it, and will still get better... 9.5/10
P.S I don't really write reviews for games, but The Forest definetely deserved one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1:
I've crash landed on a strange island. Don't know how I survived, but I think I caught a glimpse of some strange tribal man before I lost consciousness. After I awoke I set to the business of building a shelter. Who knows how long it'll be till I'm rescued.

Day 2: The tribals seem unfriendly. They showed up at the edge of my camp and eyed me while growling. They have clubs made out of human skulls and seem to be wearing teeth around their necks. I'm going to set up traps tonight.

Day 3: Some random skinny tribal tried to eat me! He came into my camp giggling and laughing, I had to kill him with my axe! Its the first time I've killed anyone. I dumped his body outside of camp. I don't like to look at it.

Day 4: The more healthy tribals tried to siege my camp today. Attacked me uprovoked but a few of my traps caught them. I killed the last man with a more modern axe I scavenged from a camp. They'll not catch me unprepared again. I'm not dying on this bloody island.

Day 5: After seeing that they have some kind of displays made out of human remains, I decided to do the same. It was disguisting and unthinkable but maybe now they'll realize this place is dangerous and give me some peace. Got a little hunting done too.

Day 6: I've been forced to build a wall around the perimeter. The healthier, smarter tribals seem to be warded off by my effigy but the starving ones are desperate enough to risk attacking. I'm going to fortify this place. I'm not becoming somone's lunch.

Day 7: While checking my traps outside camp I was attacked by some kind of weird tribal leader with armor made out of human arms. He and his war party were no match for my defenses. I stuck their heads outside camp. Maybe now they'll learn what will happen should they come here again.

Day 10: I've been a little too busy to write in my journal recently. I decided to take the fight to them and burned one of their camps with molotovs. A week ago, their screams would have bothered me. Now I was just relieved. Maybe now I'll be able to sleep at night.

Day 11: A huge monster with a ton of legs busted in through my outer wall. Fortunately I'd stashed away some explosives, so that made quick work of it. On closer examination this thing seems to be made out of...people. Sewn or mutated together somehow. What is happening in this place!?

Day 15: I cut off the heads of every tribal leader and put them on sticks. The sticks litter the outside of my camps. They'll regret the day they attacked my camps. I'll kill every last one of them if I have to. Even those mutant monsters will die.

Day 20: I decided to start adding legs to the effigies. It seems to complete them a little more. Even the starving tribals are wary of attacking me now. They know that death has come among them.

Day 30: I'd been so busy fighting off these tribals I didn't get a chance to hunt for days at a time. Haven't had time to write in my journal either. I'd walked into one of their camps I'd ransacked and saw an arm stick cooking on a spit. I was so hungry I took a bite. It wasn't too bad actually. I'm trying not to think about it.

Day 45: I added arms and legs pointing in different directions to each of my effigies to spell out YMCA". Nothing really else to do to pass my time here. When I was putting them up
date: I ate one of the legs. I was very hungry and none of my traps have been yielding any fruit
recommended:
but these perfectly good limbs have been sitting here all this time...

Day 62: I'm starting to like it here...All the limbs I can eat. Good sunshine by the beach. This island isn't so bad.

10/10 would decend into madness again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

JUNE 4TH, 2015 UPDATE: The game is very polished at this point with a few bugs here and there. I highly recommend playing it with a friend too although multiplayer can be somewhat laggy sometimes. Fantastic game with great devs who care about the game and haven't let up since release.

NOVEMBER 1ST UPDATE: This game is what early access games should be. Since my last update they have piled on gigabites of patches and the game is fully playable and optimised. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival games, but beware, do not expect to survive long. This game is hard and if you don't play smart, you will die within the first day. I'd now give the game a 8.5/10.

JUNE 16TH UPDATE: The devs for the game just optimised the absolute crap out of this game. I have gone from getting 15 fps on maximum graphics to a steady 50 fps on maximum. Before the game was terribly optimised and would lag, even on the lowest settings, now it feels literally like it looks in the trailer! Fantastic job dev team! You guys are awesome!


ORIGINAL RELEASE REVIEW: After playing 10 hours of this game, I can safely say that this is going to be one of the best survival games you could likely ever ask for. It is missing a lot of things and game isn't really stable right now, but this game is going to be amazing, mark my words. If you want to get in early, spend the 15 dollars to help the devs because it's going to be between 30-45 dollars when it is released.

If you're after a Minecraft/Rust/DayZ experience with a side of horror, you will enjoy this when it's finished I guarantee.

I'd give this game a 7/10 as of the very first release. I've been following the 4 man dev team for The Forest for nearly 2 years now and I honestly expect great things from this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING:
I'm only recommending this game because of the direction it's going, it's awesome developers, and it's very high promise.

PROS:
- Very awesome concept, lots of promise, great developers that give great updates about the progress of the game.
- Cheap investment with potentially high returns of a $30-$50 game.
- Very cool plot, reminds me of Bioshock (even a similar intro sequence) but you're stuck in a forest with a bunch of 28 Days Later style zombies/monsters
- Crafting system is easy, awesome, and very useful for when you find a safe place to settle
- The gathering/hunting/inventory/survival aspects are all very realistic and fun to do, unlike Rust.
- Very gorgeous game for it's level of development

CONS:
- The save feature is atrocious. Had to start over several times and got so annoyed I've stopped playing.
- The enemies are very easy to kill, not scary at all, and far and few between. Not at all like the trailer and getting attacked is a rarity. Making setting traps feel useless.
- It's basis of survival is very easy to achieve. Took me about 3-4 hours to have a log cabin, a ♥♥♥♥ ton of traps, wood/sticks stockpiled, and a wall all around my area. I think I was attacked maybe twice over the entire time and it was by singular enemies.
- Zero objectives. The intro makes it out like you're gonna try and find your child while fending off this enemy horde and trying to survive on this remote island but there's literally nothing to do. I got so bored that I explored the entire island, collected all the pages of my survival book, attacked large mobs of the weird people with only an axe and lived.
- Physics are off. I'll walk into a random zombie encampment and the tables and chairs will randomly shoot straight into the air. When I chop down trees the logs explode and I'll have to chase them down.

CONCLUSION:
If you got the money and the patience, go ahead and buy it; even if you don't plan on installing it for awhile. It's got a lot right going for it. A few bugs that are easy to work out and some difficulty/objective issues to smooth out but other than that it's a great game for being in just alpha. The developers give frequent updates on the game that make it easy to follow even if you don't decide to install it just yet. I feel like my money is actually going toward a great project with this game instead of others I've invested in that turned crap (Rust, Nether, etc.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Just a note that this game is still in alpha so alot of this review may become reduntant as the game progresses)

Visuals / Programming
I've had the Forest for a while now, the first thing I would like to say is that this game looks amazing, the textures are nice (Where the scenery is completed) the animations are nice and it just looks superb, it also seems fairly easy to run as far as I can tell in terms of performance.

Now the game may look amazing but unfortunately at times I find the movement a bit dated for want of a better word.  The   hit detection seems to be somewhat lacking on the smaller objects and there is a large ammount of bugs which is to be expected for a game in it's alpha.  At this time the map is not complete and i do admit feels rather small once explored which takes maybe an hour, this would not be so much of an issue for me if they made these areas less accessible ( For example walking into a cave which seems to go on forever only to find it leads nowhere only to find yourself falling through the map.) Apart from this and some rather incomplete structures and tools the creation seems rather fluid so far.

Music
The music is amazing, it really feels like you are there hearing what the player hears, the effects all sound really solid and realistic, and the screams from the Cannibals are just chilling. It makes for some really intense moments.
Gameplay
The forest is a horror survival game wherein you are crashed on an island inhabited by Cannibles and mutants, the key is to well ...survive. You will have to scavenge around the map for crafting materials where you can then proceed to build a range of shelters, traps and storage Etc. The building system is really nice and the structures look good in environment, (give or take a couple).  There are a variety of supplies and debris from previous inhabitants and the plane crash scattered around the island generally containing crucial items for you. The one thing I dislike about this is the lack of variety, once found there is no challenge to find the items again.

The Cannibals have scattered villages strewn across the island, with totems and effigies marking patrol routes, I personally found the Ai really good in this game, they will circle you; retreat; patrol; and even give the illusion of planning attacks. They are one of the best features of the game and hopefully more will be added to the villages as they are really empty right now and some future developement could prove very interesting.

When killed you will be transported to a cave system which can sometimes be infested with Cannibals or mutants which seem to only exist in the caves for now. It's a nice mechanic, like a second chance to escape and survive without losing straightaway, the notion being that after being beaten you were dragged into the Cannibals nest". The only problem I have currently is that the cave systems all look incredibly similar and lots do not have a clear exit. (Which may be interpreted as a part second chance) But personally I found it downright frustrating at times.

Mulitplayer
Recently added was a multiplayer feature
date: really nice addition but feels badly incomplete
recommended: player models look clunky and animation is not done well as of yet. No real objective means that there can be a lack of things to do
hoursPlayed: and too many players makes the game way too easy. Nice is the fact that a large ammount of players can join a single server
voteText:
although brought down by the small map size.

Conclusion
Graphics 8.5/10 - Looks amazing but Areas not complete
helpfulPercent: or textures too repetitive.\nMusic 8/10 - Really immersive and rich sounds
votesHelpful: unfortunately lacks variety after a while.\nGameplay 6.5/10  - Very nice Ai

votesFunny: Some bugs with combat and death\nMultiplayer 5/10 - Nice that it has been added

This game has significantly improved over a year. The game has terrifying moments from both jumpscares and just gritty, stark atmosphere. I can't play this game alone, only co-op. I would never leave camp.

They come for you so fast. Small groups at first, but then they learn that you are building and advancing. They start to come in larger groups and mutated versions that will haunt your dreams.

Some improvements I wish to see:

*Balancing of some of the sounds (sometimes they are too loud and the ones that are too loud can't be heard when they should be audible).

*Less AI dumbness of walking into the fire (sometimes its useful, but othertimes you just run around a fire until they eventually touch it and burn).

*The bow and arrow is inaccurate and hitboxes on the mutants are difficult to hit when you know you are hitting them. (Add some headshots).

*Colors/textures on Effigies and stronger mutants (they look like blobs, still terrifying, but could use some features).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best survival games out there, no doubt about it.

The first time I played this game I spent the first night scared out of my mind surrounded by cannibals trying to eat me! Never been so scared by a game, or movie for that mather. Slowly I learned how to survive the first nights and how to build a quite decent life. This is a beautiful and fun game and all other survival games should learn from it! It got an unique feel to it that is hard to put in words.

Over time there has been added alot more features, heck when I first bought this game you could only build a basic shelter and firepit. And the intromovie was just a demonstration with bad graphics and animations. But the developers have really made progress and added alot of content since then! I'm really excited for the future!

I have to admit I don't play it very often and when I do it's in short bursts(its been more than the 6.3 hours that steam is showing tho). But everytime I come back to check out the progress I always get positivly surprised!

My only question is WHERE THE ♥♥♥♥ IS TOMMY?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest-
The Forest houses both the survival and horor genre in a new light. The survival genre is one of my faveorite and The Forest did its self justice. It incorporates crafting systems, fighting, and exploring in such inventive ways. It has many versitile facets that lets the user customize their experience and play. As it goes with open world games this one is great. It lets you chop down almost any tree in the game, hunt a varity of animals (Lizards, Rabits, Fish), and build housing. With the new release of co-op play people can combined survival ideas with friends and pull the game to new heights. The Forest is a game i would recomend highly to anyone who wants a challenge, likes the suvival and horror genre, and anyone who wants to have fun. I Would rate this game 9/10. Despite its many key facts for being a great game there is some room for improvement. I hope for the future release of things such as a customizable character, more buildables, a large map and so on. The Forest is coming up on its beta release and i hope to see many new assets factored into the game and in the future. With time The Forest Will only get beter and better. Great Game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Good (as of v14):
- Open World, Semi-Sandbox
- Full survival features: thirst, hunger, hypothermia, sleep, infection, etc
- In depth crafting: trees can be cut down, plants harvested, animals hunted, weapons ugraded. etc
- Homebase: Can build a variety of structures, including a home/fort
- Highly intelligent enemy AI
- Beautiful Graphics
- Addictive and engaging

The Bad:
- No crosshair.  This makes aiming with projectile weapons extremely difficult.  This is compounded by the fact that obtaining the materials to craft/find said projectile weapons is time consuming and arduous enough on its own.  So you can imagine the irritation one gets when you think you are throwing a molotov or shooting a bow/fare at the enemy, but instead it veers off in a completely different direction.
Suggested solution:  Have a crosshair appear as soon as a projectile weapon is equiped.  Or, at the very least, allow a crosshair to be toggled on or off in the options menu.

- Lack of motivation to keep surviving.  Reason 1, no quests or direction.  There needs to be a driving force behind the survival.  Otherwise once you've built a fort and explored and collected everything (which isnt much) the game is simply, eat - drink - sleep - mess with cannibals - repeat.  Which get boring fast.   Reason 2, very little possible items to find.  There needs to be at least 4 or 5 times more variety of items to find/craft and weapons to be found.  If there is no story to drive me to the play the game, then there needs to be the promise of an abundace of rare, hidden loot to drive me to keep exploring and surviving against the elements and cannibals.  Right now, there is simply a miniscule amount of this.  There are literally only 2 clubs, 3 axes (which are very weak against enemies, oddly enough), a stick, a rock, a weak sauce stick-spear, a molotov, weak-sauce bow, and flare gun.  And the melee weapons all do very similar damage amounts.  Also, like I mentioned before, the projectile weapons are almost impossible to use without a crosshair.

- The island is not large enough.  We either need an island about 3 or 4 times larger, or multiple islands/areas we can explore.  Another solution would be to have the island seed be completely randomly generated on each new game.  Not just have the pieces of it be re-arranged each time you start a new game (like it is now).

- The cannibals take WAY TOO MANY HITS to kill.  If realism is what they are going for, I shouldn't have to hit a cannibal in the head with a hand axe over 8 times to kill it.  The cannibals should go down with half the hits it currently takes.  Conversely, if it takes me 8 hits to kill an unarmored cannibal with a hand axe, then why does it take a cannibal only 2 or 3 hits with their club (or just 3 or 4 with their bare hands) to kill an unarmored player?  That makes no sense.

- There are far too many bugs with the traps you can make.  Particularly the noose trap and birthday trap.  Cannibals who get caught in the noose bug out and spin in giant loops around the map.  And cannibals that get stuck in the birthday trap appear to be dead, but when you reset the trap and try to retrieve the corpse, they either come back to life, or change into a completely different cannibal and start attacking you.

Final thoughts:
I completely recommened this game as a low cost early access title.  You'll get a good 10-20 hours out of it until you run out of stuff to do.  However, I cannot justify paying any more for it at the time of its release unless they add much more content and address some of the issues I mentioned.  But, if they do fix what I mentioned, this game has the potential to rival the popularity of Skyrim/Minecraft.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This despite being alpha/beta, or what ever the term used to describe a game at this point in its development,  is enjoyable.
Pros
+ Decent sized map, and due to the terrain and foliage, its easy to get lost.
+ Regardless of how long you have lived in the game, how much resources you have obtained, groups of enemys will still startle you.
+ The number of resources one can obtain and use is massive in number.
+ The crafting system is being added too and as is, very pratical in design.(Traps, homes, fires, weapons, ext)
+ Wide variety of selection of food, there is more than just chicken.(Deer, fish, lizard, rabit, people, etc)
+ The game has a countdown in the main menu that is only there to inform the player of when the next update is.
+ The game encourages you to exsplore.
+ Graphics are high quality.
+ Combat is challenging and fluid.
+ Variety of enemys.

Negatives
- Glichy, glichy, glichy. I could list a wide variety of potential gliches but they are constantly being fixed, and being created; and everyone exsperiences different ones. Some exsperience near none (Like me, thus all reviews are bias as a result)
- Enemys, despite being mutated humans, they have a strong resistance to weapons in a way that makes little to no sense.(Large no longer huminode mutants exlcuded, those things are hulks of flesh amd should be a threat)
- Some crafted items make littles sense in the real world (Such as the timed bomb, Upgraded spear using bone and not stone)
- The canibals will sometimes glich out after hiting traps and permantly be gliched.
- It is normaly required for you to start over after each update, this happens (on adverage every ten days)
- Animals have no sense of self preservation. (I watched bird after bird fly into my bonfire)
- The terrain has a few graphical gliches (Ground is invisible in some places, though very minor in size)
- The plane crash (starting area) use to be random, now its not.
- Few feet equals death while jumping


To clarify, this game is still IN DEVELOPMENT and I can't stress that enough. All these negatives and even postives may be made worse or better during the time they work on this.

Summary.
Worth it, its fun had a good time, still play every now and again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

About 5 hours into the game so far, time for a first review (updates will follow) as this game really deserves one :)

I read a few reviews and watched several Let's Plays as I was hesitant to buy another Early Access game and being so very used to buying games on sale I felt like the full price of 15€ might be too much... now I must say the very positive reviews were all correct and I would gladly pay full price again! Even FULL price like 50€ or so.
Sure, there are still some minor alpha bugs, but I've honestly seen released games (at 50€) that had way more problems! And nothing game breaking here, mostly glitches, lighting or stuff that still has to be added.

Pros / What I like/love about The Forest:

- Freedom! This really feels like an open world in which YOU decide what to do.
- Adventure! Really feels like you're out there, lost in the wilderness, trying to make it through the nights and building shelters, collecting rain water, hunting small animals, exploring, washing off the blood/dirt to avoid infections etc.
- Beauty of nature! I didn't expect it at first, but the game looks awesome! Finally we have a real" forest that is dense

- Details: You can feel Endnight's love for details when you chop down a tree and it really falls and isn't just added to your inventory or when you open said inventory and your backpack is spread out on a blanket on the ground in front of you etc.

Cons:
Might become too easy over time? Don't know but it doesn't feel as brutal as other survival games (just played The Long Dark e.g.

With each update, the game gets better and better. 9/10. Totally Reccommend

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very tense.  My first try I looted the luggage from the airplane I was on that crashed.  I encountered a primitive that quickly ran off.  I began gathering lumber to try to make a shelter, however, I noticed another primitive.  This made me cautious so I became hyper vigilant, always looking over my shoulder.  The next thing I knew there was some sort of hunting party of primitives chasing after me.  I ran for a while until I found a beach.  Out in the ocean there was a boat.  I was starving so I figured I'd see if maybe there was some food.  What I found were sharks.  They ate me.  My next try I gathered supplies again from the wrecked aircraft and then took off.  I ran for a while until I found a small island out in the middle of a lake.  I set up camp there and painstakingly constructed a shelter while swimming to and fro from the island to the shore to gather lumber.  There's blueberries on the island so that's what I've been eating.  I seem to be outside of the primitives' territory.  For now, I'll stay on Blueberry Island until I figure what I should do next.  However, the clear and present threat of death persists.  It's only a waiting game now...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I tried to like this game, I really did. I cannot recall the last time I was so excited to purchase a PC title. $15 for this beautiful game? How could I not buy it? 90% rating on Steam? How could I not buy it? Recently added multiplayer mode? How could I not buy it? An open world game with survival and horror elements? That's right up my alley! Unfortunately sometimes we as humans become enamored with items that are hyped and advertised heavily. Often times we might even suffer from buyer's remorse. I'm not going to bash the developers or trash this game." I just want to throw out my honest ideas and feelings about this game.

The game really is visually stunning. I can only think of a handful of EA games that can compare. Shader details are good and the attention to detail is extremely impressive. Game mechanics are buttery smooth and make for an enjoyable gameplay experience. Interacting with objects is quite nice and just in general has a realistic feel to it. Optimization (for me anyway) is quite good. I get decent framerate while having the game on max settings. No one is going to dispute the graphics
date: mechanics or optimization for this game.\n\nBut can a game thrive simply by giving you solid graphics
recommended: mechanics and optimization? Unfortunately for The Forest
hoursPlayed: it just doesn't have a whole lot more to offer. Crafting and gathering gets repetitive quite fast and the balance of thirst/hunger is just bad. I feel like my player is constantly hungry or thirsty or just doesn't have any stamina left despite eating large quantities of food. The balance of combat is also leaves a lot to be desired. Hitting a mutant can take 10
helpfulPercent: or 12 times just to kill it. I'm hit 3 or 4 times and I'm dead. It's so unbalanced and needs a whole makeover IMHO. Speaking of mutants

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day - 1

I awaken dazzed and bloodied quickly scavenging things around the crash site, i can hear howls and screams getting closer. I grab all i can and run in to the woods, the lanescape is so full of wildlife, but i hear a strange sound to my right so i decide to to investigate. When what evers making the noise comes into sight through the tree line i can see 3 tribesman all crouched in a circle, i choose to push forward to get a better look. I am as close as i can get and i am shocked, the 3 tribesman are EATING SOMEONE. Theres another close to them with a skull mounted on a stick above his head just watching, i think he's the captin. I'd better leave, im in no position to fight 4 men with just a axe.

Night has fallen and i have almost contructed a basic shelter, it's starting to rain I should build a fire to cook the meat i've hunted. i continue to chop wood when i hear a new strange sound behind me, I turn instantly to check it out and theres a tribesman just stood there. Watching me, he says nothing he does nothing we stand for about a minute staring at each other locked in this gaze. Suddenly he howls turns and runs, i pick up leaves to wipe my ♥♥♥♥ (♥♥♥♥ myself).

Day - 2

Since i was discovered theres been alot more patrols around my camp it's becoming increasinly hard to gather precious resources, but i press on starting to see if i can start on a cabin when i hear a scream in the distance. It sounds like a womens in trouble, against my better judgement i go to seek out the source of this skin scrawling screech. I heard it again i am getting closer, i come to a clearing and decide to duck down behind the tree's to check the area out. I can see a total of 6 tribesman 4 in a pack and 2 wandering (appeared to be anyway), when all of a sudden i see the captin arch his back and let out a bellowing scream (the same i heard that made me investigate). ♥♥♥♥ it's a trap! I turn to escape before i am seen but my fears have already been realised, theres a tribes-woman behind me, god knows how long she was there but as soon as she knows i've seen her she turns and runs. I run in the oposite direction but it's to late, I'm being hunted! I take a breather to eat to recover stamina and i have a quick look to see if their still on my trail but i can't see much. I can see a single light in the distance well out of reach, it's the captin looking for me then all of a sudden i hear a loud THUD. I frantically turn in every direction to see what it was but theres nothing there...

HOLY ♥♥♥♥ THEIR IN THE TREE'S

3 men drop down around me and instantly signal the captin, theres no more running it's now or never. we all start hacking at each other franticly, i need to drop one before the captin closes in. I manage to kill one and wound another, but before i could finish him a tribes-woman appeared from the bushes to drag him away. I still have two of these ♥♥♥♥ers trying to cave my head in i can't afford to turn my back to chase, I'm about to die, the captin is unscathed and the grunt is so close to death when i knock him down. I instantly raise my axe when (CRUNCH) i am dead.

Day - ???

I awake in a cave in complete darkness, i use my lighter to check where i am when to my horror i discover i am in some sort of meat gathering chamber. Theres bodies handing from the ceiling everywhere, atleast 40 all dismembered differently. The floor is littered with the body parts of previous victims, How long have they been here? There wasn't many people on the plane, no where near enough for this. I check my inventory and to my supprise i still have all my gear not that i have much that can help. It's to quiet nothing but the sound of water drops, after a quick search i find the exit and a flare gun THIS SHOULD HELP! Ii have to crouch low to leave this cave and follow this route. It's never ending cave expansion after expansion limbs after limbs when will this end! I start to hear a new a very ♥♥♥♥ing freaky sound from the next opening, Luckily theres ambeinent light coming from a pool of water so i switch my light off. I can see something in the distance and it's big, I tread closer at a snails pace around the slight corner to get a better look only to find theres another 2 meteres away.

I am unsure if they can see me or let alone at all so i decide to get the ♥♥♥♥ outta dodge and make a dash for the exit, i can see light and i've been going through room after room i have to be close to the surface! I make it to the next section without them noticing but it's not getting any better. the light turned out to be a fire, a fire being used be at least 12 of the grunts and women. Bricks were ♥♥♥♥. I make a dash for the exit (or atleast what appeared to be) OH MY GOD as i run crouch run through the space to escape i notice teeth dangling from strings. I don't have time to look i have to get out and now, as i am escaping i come into more rooms like the last filled with more grunts. it feels like im being chased by the entire tribe and i dare not look back. I finally come to the surface, it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ down with rain and pitch black i can use this to my advantage and escape through the tree line stopping for nothing.

I escaped with my life for now....

10/10 i know this is not a review but i wanted to share my first experience with the game and i am so impressed.

£10.99 well spent i look forward to content updates

I decide to push the raft along and find a more suitable beach for life. I dock my raft in a little pond of invisible water right by the shore. I immediately place a large house. It requires 82 logs. I slave away until night time lumberjacking my hands off. After I put the last log I had into the house, I still had 12 logs left to collect. Then it dawned on me. I had no shelter made. I hastily put together a ramshackle standing fire and huddled by it as the natives gathered closer. Eventually the fire died as did I. By now, I was just so done. I just ran out of the caves and got killed by a native right as I came out. I turned off my computer. I just sat there, looking at a black, empty screen.

10/10 would die again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me tell you exactly why you should buy this game.
Don't let the fact that it's early access dissuade you from purchasing this gem. Unlike most early access game, the devs work around the clock to find and fix new bugs, review consumer feedback, implement new features into the game, and generally improve the game in each and every update that they release. The major updates are usually released once every month, while smaller updates (bugfixes) are usually released about 2-4 times a month.
There is a ton to do in this game. The building takes such a long time, but it's because of this long arduous process that when it's finally done it's all the more rewarding. The buildings look practical; like something that you could, and would actually build in the wilderness.
Now on to gameplay. The game feels very relaxing at first. The sound of the forest will build up a false sense of security. It's for this reason that the horror aspect is so effective. When I say horror I mean horror. This game will make you afraid of the night, and when you do finally build that fortress you won't want to leave it. The combat is rough, but it's not impossible to take on 3 mutants and survive leaving all of them dead. With the right tactics you can bring the fight to them. The resource gathering is probably the most unique of any game; very realistic and enthrolling. The inventory system works great too, and you can find everything you have in the first glance. The crafting aspect of the game is simple too, but it feels like something that could be done in real life with the same ingredients.
Don't let the system requirements dissuade you either. I play this on my laptop when I'm on vacation. My laptop has 4 GBs of RAM, and no graphics card. I set all the settings on the lowest I can, and still play the game. It doesn't look very good after that, but it's still a fun game to play.
In short, this game is fun, arduous, unforgiving, and rewarding. It stands out among the many titles being released these days. It's a shiny diamond in a bed of coal, and it's well worth 15 dollars US. Buy this game. You won't regret it.

Just want to add even more to this review. The Dev's are awesome. They've added loads of new content and fixed tons of bugs since the release of this game. It's 100x better now since I upgraded my GPU. It's a truly beautiful game.

It's also truly terrifying if you don't build a base. If you want pure horror, just run around in the woods and scavenge for food. Christ, the mutants are probably the scariest thing I've ever encountered. You never quite know when they are there, and you want to stay out of the woods, but you know you need to go in for food/supplies, and that's when they get you. The weakest ones, the starving mutants, are definitely the scariest. They are skinny and bloody, run at you really quickly, and overall just make you crap your pants. Even worse, there are ambient sounds in the woods now that sound like leaves/branches falling, so it's even harder to tell when they are running up behind you. I don't think i've ever been so terrified while playing a game before. It's not even the mutants most of the time, it's the idea that they are lurking behind me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survival games have become the hottest genre as of late. It does not matter if you are trying to survive alone against the wilderness, zombies, or other players. Survival will often make you do things you might not. This game is no exception.

You are sitting next to a window on an airplane with a little boy holding your arm. You are given little clue as to who you are or who he is before the front of the airplane is ripped off and you are falling fast to the Earth below. Upon landing, you see a native (given the number of body parts on the island, I would say cannibal) take the little boy and leave. As you get up, you have little time to gather what you can scavenge around you before others are sure to come. And come they will.

Starting off with only rocks and sticks, I grab a huge rock and began to bust open luggage, managing to find some rations and supplies. As I wandered, I could find other make shift camps but no one around, at least no one I wanted to bother with...yet. After starting a fire to cook a rabbit (seagulls, turtles, and other animals can be killed), nightfall began to set in. I had began to make a shelter but lacked logs to complete it. Then came flashlights waving around in the dark.

I was not ready for a confrontation yet so I ran and began to explore. The island I landed on had caves to explore, water all around, another another island nearby with snowcapped mountains. Upon realizing I lacked any means to get logs for my shelter, I doubled back to where the flashlights had been to find my hunters were still near by. Armed with a makeshift spear, I began to attack them, killing two before the lights out.

I awoke to a macabre horror. I was trapped in a dark cave, half filled with water, with bodies hanging from the ceiling all around me. With a lighter that constantly had to get lit (water will do that to it), I found a lot more supplies along with an axe, and a few other weapons. I found this helped my struggle quite a bit as I was able to escape underground after awhile, surfacing at last the claustrophobic tunnels.

Fresh air and daylight, my new day began with heading back towards my shelter I was trying to build. I had started it on top of a cliff with a giant tree nearby, making it easy for me to find when needed. I learned my new found weapon doubled as a means to chop down trees to help me finish my shelter. Before I could finish, another group of cannibals found me. This time, I did not wake up in a cave. This time, it was the end.

With this being an alpha build, it is easy to pass off graphical glitches (water in the game often looks off and broken when in it). I once had a turtle I could not smash with my rock and when viewing my inventory, the turtles image never left my screen, covering up what it was I was trying to see. The game sounded authentic once on the ground but I had hoped for more of a build up leading to the crash (the front of the airplane disappeared without a sound and I never once heard the boy next to me utter a sound). The natives are incredibly quiet and I had expected to be able to hear them once they got close, but this was not the case. Not even when I was attacking them did I hear them utter a grunt. I had one guy I beat on repeatedly and he eventually ran away despite the number of times I impaled him with my spear but the next guy went down with just a few thrusts.

The game is very intuitive in that it was easy to learn how to use what was around me very quickly. On screen prompts when seeing berries to eat, supplies to scavenge, or and how to duck were very helpful. Despite not being very good at survival games, I found what I discovered in this game to very enjoyable, even at this early of release. I definitely look forward to seeing what the developers have in store and the game has a handy count down on the main menu to let you know when to expect the next update. And expect I shall. I look forward to my next trip to The Forest as I learn from my mistakes and work on my survival skills(Tip: don't build your shelter too far away from logs you will need to cut down, if you can find an axe that is).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYou are the sole surivor of an airplane crash on a remote island.  Your fellow passangers, who by judging from the contents of their suitcases were tennis players that were hopped up on prescription drugs.  You obviously were not one of them given how you whine and complain about being cold and wet hungry and thirsty and tired all the time.  It's ironic that you were the one who survived.  The island itself is beautiful and you can choose to live in the snow capped mountains or a tropical beach and it's not without its cast of colorful characters- mainly cannibales in various stages of mutation.  Would I recommend this game absolutley!!! I have almost 200 hours logged in playing.  Given that it's an alpha build you have to be patient with the devlopers its not without its glitches and bugs but unlike other games I have played, the developers are always working on it to fix problems and add new content.  If you like survival games where you have to build cabins, tree houses hunt and fish or explore caves then this is the game for you.  One of the BEST features that is included are the cheat modes- put in by the developers.  If you just want to play as a survivor with no mutants you can.  If you want to play with them just coming out at night you can.  I thought the game was worth the money especially given that is is always evolving

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you want to survive a plane crash?

Do you want to build a forest base?

Do you want commune with nature to protect yourself from the insane cannibalistic mutants that live on the island with you?

Do you want to have a bit of an existential crisis when the first cannibals come up to you and are curious as to what you are doing destroying they're beautiful forest, and you decide to slaughter all of them so they can't report back?

If you said yes to any of these questions, The Forest is for you.

Yes it's buggy, yes it's early access, but it's entertaining and fun to play.

Thank you Endnight Games

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not much time in game yet, still trying to work out some kinks myself especially with saving/loading. But somehow, this game designed by a small team, runs smoother and has greater gameplay then some of the damn major company releases that are failing miserably (Ubisoft AC:UNITY comes to mind...).

That being said, if you plan to purchase the game: IT IS ALPHA. This isnt the final product, so keep that in mind. You are basically paying so you can test the game and aid the dev team.

System Specs:
AMD FX6300 3.5ghz
8gb DDR3
GeForce 770 OC 2gb
1TB WD Black Sata HDD

One thing I will say, is the way the AI works for enemies. Now there are still a few bugs; Cannibals getting stuck on a rock here and there, or blatantly ignoring you until you slap em. But the AI is actually pretty entertaining. Scouting parties will roam around with a flashlight in the dark and actually appear from a distance like survivors. They will roam and look for you if they see a fire. They sometimes leave a person behind that will remain in the area to keep scouting while they move on. And they are F*ckin Vicious lol. If you want to break away from the mindless, boring zombie apocalypse survival games that just launch slow moving easily killed zombies, check this one out.

I haven't gotten to build much, but I like that the game provides a mini-survival book with some essentials and guidelines - but also provides the blueprints to enable self-made homes and barriers instead of jus Your shack must look like this". Oh and don't run over your firepit... bad things happen.

Graphically

recommended: it runs very smooth on high for me. As well as looking MUCH nicer than most of the newer games I played. There is still some glitching with water and such

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest is a game where you are a plane crash survivor, seeing your son get taken away by a mysterious figure. You exit the plane after you wake up fully and see a beautiful forest, light shafts peering through the leaves. You have a survival book, some soda, some protein bars, and an axe you found lodged in the head of an innocent flight attendant in the plane. You need to survive, if you don't you die. (No ♥♥♥♥) Now that i'm done with the summary, let me just say, this game is amazing. Yes, it used to be buggy, but it really has come a long way. I, as well as many of the other backers/buyers of early access are VERY proud of the developers for getting this far in development. They are still actively developing this great game, and I am satisfied.

Graphics: 8.9/10 (Very beautiful graphics)
UI: 7.5/10 (Pretty solid)
Animations: 8/10 (Great)
Multiplayer/Co-Op: 6/10 (Good, just wish there were better implemented systems and more character models!)
Singleplayer: 10/10 (TERRIFYING)
Crafting: 9/10 (Very unique)
Enemies/Cannibals: 10/10 (Creepy, Insane, VERY well done)
Content Amount: 7.8/10 (Not an insane amount, wish there was a bit more)
Map Design/Size: 8/10 (Pretty big and nicely done)
Community: 6/10 (Small, quiet, friendly)

Overall Rating: 8.4/10 (Very well done, but not finished yet. It's not a triple AAA title by any means, but it is a great game, and deserves this rating and recoginition.

Reason I gave this rating is because I generally like this game. I am no fan boy by any means, but have been following the development since the 3rd Quarter of 2014, and I can say the game has come very far! I, as many others do look forward to the further development of this game.

How many hours will you get out of this game no matter who you are? Between 30-160 (You won't get very much replayability out of the game as of now)
Thank you for reading my review. If you would like to see more of my reviews, check out my profile.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:

+Breathtaking Graphics

+Great Sounds

+Great Survival Roots

+Interesting Enemies (They themselves are an interesting group)

+Interesting Enemy AI (Don't expect full hostility. The tribe doesn't just want to take you down... Not at first anyways)

+Natural Fear as Opposed to Forced

+Co-Op (Haven't tried it yet, but that's the next step)

+A Constant Sense of Urgency

+A Clock of When the Next Update is

Cons that are possibly related to it being in Early Access:

-Extreme Lack of Content at this point (There is no story besides the intro cutscene. Currently the only thing to do is to.. survive and explore. I'm hoping for the different optional paths in the story. Such as saving the kid who is probably your son, escaping the island, joining one of the tribes, eliminating the mutants or sealing off the caves and other such things)

-Bugs (Nothing gamebreaking for me so far. Some floating rocks, the ability to walk through dead trees and drying racks, but nothing big)

-Would greatly benefit from random events! The enemys are great, but as of right now there is no motive to put yourself in the action... I think I stayed up only one night and nothing happened. Would be interesting for a Bermuda Triangle type deal! Electronics stop working in the area, resulting in many plane and boat disappearances... which you can explore and rescue survivors and they become companions(yes/no?) The point is there isn't a whole lot of action yet... (I'm sure they will add content of some sort)

-Not many weapons (There are axes, clubs, bows, spears and one katana. You can only craft axes, bows and clubs. The other stuff you have to find. The bow doesn't do anything to mutants, so that leaves axes and clubs, which the club for me is too slow, so really my only option is an axe.)

-Death isn't anything to worry about, making the game... not as scary. When you die, the mutants drag you to a cave and conveniently leave you with all your stuff and right by the entrance of the cave. Not only that, but the cave and village above the cave are full of powerful loot (Dynamite and Modern Axes). I've died 3 or 4 times and everytime there were no monsters anywhere so I just grabbed loot and went back home. It is almost rewarding to die. The only way to fully die that I've seen is to die and be taken to the cave and then die again inside the cave... so the creatures don't scare me anymore. (Maybe they haven't finished the death sequence?)

-Creatures become much less eerie after getting a pattern. At first it feels like you can't even kill one monster, but really if you set them on fire or knock them to the ground and pound on their head it's pretty simple. Especially since their AI isn't very unique during fights. All they do is stay a small distance and circle you and then when confident they come in and attack. When they attack they do more flailing then anything strategic. Would be nice to see the packs surround you and take you out. One man shouldn't be able to take on two, let alone 3-5. It would be nice if they were dangerous enough to make me want to hide. (Could be fixed with additions to AI)

-No destruction of enemy bases (I don't think they are going to add this, but... it would be nice to be able to disable the tribes foothold.

Cons?:
-I'm kind of on the fence about this one... there are the normal tribesmen and they are beautifully done (except the linear combat), but there are also mutants" that are part of the tribes... they are basically big tanks and me personally... I think it kind of kills the scare factor. It doesn't scare me that a slow
date: giant made of multiple arms and legs is swinging in my direction. It's kind of creepy that I have to throw three sticks of dynamite to kill him
recommended: but other than that... not really. I want enemies that are smarter and faster than I am. The normal tribesmen aren't scary because of their looks or strength. They are scary because there are hundreds of them
hoursPlayed: they not only want to harm you
voteText: but they stalk you... you are their prey. They are hunting you... and they are... well they are supposed to be good at it. I think I'd prefer just the tribe
helpfulPercent: but the big mutants also have their pros. For instance
votesHelpful: in the trailer I saw one break down a whole wall to let the rest of the tribe in... I would've **** my pants... but I haven't seen anything like that happen so.\n\n-I'm just being knit-picky here
votesTotal: but seriously what are the chances that not only your plane crashes and you survive
votesFunny:
but you land on an island filled with cannibal mutants and find a convenient survival guide and hatchet?

-I can't really think of much for cons that aren't just because it's in early access... There is no toggle crouch button!

Summary: Great game that is only $15! Right now
commentsCount: I got 8 hours of singleplayer gameplay just from the survival aspects. It is my opinion that when the full game is released

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game...this ♥♥♥♥ing game...

You've recovered from the plane crash, and begun gathering supplies.
It's getting dark. You've finished gathering enough sticks to keep your fire lit for the night,
and you're on your way back to your piecemeal camp, where you lay your head til dawn....

...and then you spot him.

There's a man, quite clearly insane and probably a cannibal, creeping around outside your camp.
Do you attempt to sneak up on him and take him out silently, or simply abandon all of the work
you've done so far, taking your chances further afield somewhere within The Forest?

A blow to the back of the head makes the decision for you, and you awaken upside-down in a dark cave.
Between you and your only chance of life on the surface are a myriad of unknown horrors, dangers, and darkness.
You probably won't make it out alive... but if you do, your life will never be the same again, as you wage a one-man guerilla war on an entire tribe of the most devious creatures known to mankind.

--------------

One of the best developed, most atmospheric and incredibly satisfying survival experiences you'll ever have.
The developers add new, somewhat unexpected amounts of additional content every month, as well as constantly addressing performance issues. This is a prima facia case of Early Access being used to it's finest extent.

It's tense, it's rewarding, the systems are fantastic and the concepts are brilliant.
The graphics are STUNNING, and the survival mechanics are the best available in the genre to date.

I can't WAIT to see the finished product, but it's worth twice the price it sells for already!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: I did what any sane person would do when crashing in a forest; Ran around and punched suitcases to steal from the dead. They didnt need it, I did. After I had my arms around 4 sticks and 2 stones, I found a convenient survival guide in my back pocket. It stated that a fire was good for morale, and I've seen Bear Gryllz, so I could confirm it. But, to aimlessly build a shelter out in the open is a bad idea. So I took a moment to gather my bearings, and placed a campfire behind a hill, near a bottleneck formation of rocks. This place was perfect. Fire was up, I caught a lizard (It was petrified from my manlyness) and cooked it. What a boost to my morale. I had heard these forests were dangerous, so I took no time to doubt, and hurried to build defensive walls around my rock formation, to keep me safe. I lost sunlight fast, and decided to call it a night. Something in the dark, deep forest was screaming, I dont know what.

Day 2: The screams from last night kept me up. I've gotten close to no sleep, my water is running out and I am low on food. I must think of something fast if I'm to survive in this unforgiving habitat. Then I remembered a technique known to noone at all. Slaughter a threatned species to use its shields to gather rainwater in. Now I had water. A human can survive for three weeks with water, and barely one without it. I made an axe out of what you would expect. Stone, some bindings and a stick.  Now I had a weapon, I was ready. I awaited the twilight, built traps and stocked up on all my most vital resources; it was going to be a long night.
After a battle in the darkness I was defeated, I dont know what I fought, but it was tough. And it dragged me to a cave. Luckily, my time in the Elite Gamer's League taught me a thing or two about survival in caves. DONT EVER USE A LIGHTER or a FLASHLIGHT; Use a torch, they are reliable. So I did. I finally saw some distant light in the cave; civilization. I was saved. I had found human beings. Here my adventure en-.. Wait, why are they naked? Hello? Why are you growling at me? That's a nice club you got the- Excuse me? I'm in time for dinner? AAGH! ♥♥♥♥!

11/10 - Bear Grylls would ♥♥♥♥ his pants again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest is still very much in development, so occasionally you will run into some awful bug - recently I was trapped in a cave, for example - but updates are regular and I find the game quite playable even as it is.

Disclaimer: I generally play with cheats on - and I love that this is an option! Mostly, I play in Vegan Mode which disables all the cannibals and turns The Forest into a creepy survival game rather than horror survival game. I enjoy exploring the map, building stuff and trying to find enough food and water to live on while avoiding freezing to death. In fact I didn't buy the game until I discovered that it could be played with cheats. However, I do think that there is a lot of the game that I miss out on because of my hypersensitive nerves. There is also Vegetarian Mode which only disables cannibals by day and Ironforest which prevents destruction of your base by cannibals/players.

I like that the mutants have their own culture and lives and one day, I swear, I will find the courage to find out more about them. If there was a cheat where I could infiltrate the cannibals and move amongst them without being attacked unless maybe I attacked them first that would just make my day.

In the meantime, the map is quite stunning, visually. However, even with the cannibals themselves disabled, the artifacts that they leave around the island can be quite disturbing so I don't recommend to someone who just wants a pretty map and no crawling skin factor.

Survival is challenging even without cannibals trying to eat your face. You need to get set up with shelter, fire, food and water pretty quickly. Saving is only possible on a bed (separate from sleeping). If you want to explore you need to make sure that you find a campsite well before dark as you can't carry enough to make a shelter in one go and trying to build at night while freezing and suddenly realising that you can't find any sticks where you are is not so fun. The map is large, but not massive, so after a while you can get bases set up around the map and things are less challenging in that respect.

I have never played the multiplayer, but I imagine that it would be a great game to play cooperatively. There are plenty of resources and it's always less scary to have a friend along when mutants are trying to kill and eat you.

Somehow, this is one of the game that I play most often, there is just something about it that keeps drawing me back. So, yes, I do recommend it. I only have 40 odd hours on record, so far, but it's one of the few games on my favourites tab, because I know I'll go back there before long even if it's just to see what the developers added in the latest patch.

TL;DR It plays well, it looks great and updates are regular. There are cheats. And cannibals.
