reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's do an assessment of each mode:
Single Player:

Whilst you play the game alone, you start to have much more nervous tendancies, this encourages The Forest's type of gameplay. Everytime you try to collect materials, try to explore, or even try to gather food, your nerves are stretched and stressed. This is mostly knowing that there could just be that large group of cannibals nearby, who are more than willing to gnaw on your ankles. I highly reccomend doing the single player before going into the multiplayer, as it has a much more survivalist horror feel to it, a feel that almost every other Early Access Game i've played attempted but in the end failed to achieve.

Multiplayer

The Multiplayer is fantastic, although that is mostly due to how much you need to expose yourself in order to gather the most basic of items, players can fully take advantage of this, and become much more of a threat than any cannibals could achieve. Although if you are working together with other players on the multiplayer, you will likely power through the game, something which is a huge issue right now with a lack of content for the 'endgame'. Don't be disheartened however, as so far the game even in multiplayer can keep it's horror-survivalist tones.

Additional Thoughts

Although this is in early access, we need a lot more content, this game has the current capabilities to become a very great game, however, that does not gaurantee it will become that.  Same as with every other Early Access. I do really hope the Devs work hard on this game, giving us more content, hopefully even allowing the game to be modded. Such content introducing things as this will create a very good game.

Graphics - The current graphics of the game are very beautiful, the skybox and rain effects are much better than i've seen in most 'AAA Titles'. Although there is some unecesary blurred textures in some areas this is an Early Access so these hopefully will be fixed.

Sound and Ambient - The sound and ambience within this game will not help to calm you, surroundings will react to you being nearby, animals will run over sticks and through bushes when your gathering, making you worried of what may be around. This adds to the theme of the game greatly.

TLDR:

Single player is gud but need some sort of endgame

Multiplayer is gud but needs more of a challenge for multiple players

Needs Mod support!

The more content that is released, the more I will enjoy this game, and I currently highly reccomend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, I've officially played enough of this game that I feel like I can give a solid reveiw (and a TL;DR version). I played this game a lot on a friend's computer, and logged in over sixty hours before I bought it myself. So, with over 100 total hours of play between single and multiplayer, I have to say -  I love this game, and I cannot play it enough.

TL;DR,

Pros
>Get to survive a plane crash
>Fight hordes of savages with some of the best AI I've come across
>Option to stay peaceful and coexist with said savages
>Cannibalism
>Sick crafting action
>Mad raft drifts
>Frequent updates with countdown to next update
>Dope Spelunking
>Horror is 11/10 levels of Nope
>You can lumberjack down the whole The Forest like it's Pioneer Simulator 2015 Elite Edition
>Looks better than Crysis 2
>Mad survival simulation; you have to keep warm, dry, clean, hydrated and well fed. Good luck.
>Close enough to reality that you'll never want to go to Vancouver Island (the island looks like its in BC, to clarify)

Cons
>Occasionally an update will be bumped back a day or two
>Official wiki is poorly maintained
>Game loses it's sheeit when you're hosting a large game
>Can't viciously murder Canadian Geese
>...

This game is fraking amazing - I really love survival horror games, and this game was the first game to give a great balance for both. I have never been truly unsettled by a vidya as much as I have The Forest. No spoilers, but there is a great and unexpected amount of body horror and truly unsettling caves. the crafting and building in this game are great, and as of version 0.18b they have both been incredibly fluid. There are frequent updates that add great new content, and every new update has cemented my love of the game. Oh, and it's fraking gorgeous. Like, for real dood - it looks better than Skyrim and a big chunk of other AAA games.

And the freedom dood - you can completely avoid conflict (a new breed of stealth) or hunt down every single other person on the island and murder (and cannibalize) them. Wanna live on a lake? Make a houseboat. Wanna live in the woods? Make a log cabin, or a treehouse. Explore the mountains and caves, looks for signs of other survivors... or just chill out and farm. The fact that there is such a small dev team that are so involved and hard at work is impressive, and as a Canadian I am astounded that they're based in British Columbia (it's great to see Canadian Content that isn't amateur as frak).

I can't recommend this game enough - it's like an HD First person version of Don't Starve,but way more indepth and a lot more realistic.
11/10, the greatest video game to come out of Canada (including GTA III and Mass Effect, yes).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a game where you just want to keep ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ yourself out if sheer terror The Forest is not for you.

But, if you're looking for a very realistic, hardcore, survival-horror game that looks absolutely gorgeous, even in alpha, The Forest is what you're looking for.

While you won't ♥♥♥♥ yourself because of any jump scares or most of the other elements of horror games, The Forest has its own brand of horror. During the day you will be able to see pretty well, but so many things around you look like the cannibalistic mutants that hunt you down. The whole time, even during the day, your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is clenched so hard you could cut through steel. Eventually after two hours of playing it becomes so exhausted you aren't able to hold your ♥♥♥♥ in anymore and then you start ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ yourself. Then somehow it gets worse at night because you can't see anything past your campfire. You will want to punch a baby right in the face from all the anxiety it gives you.

Also the deer can become submarines and go underwater so that's pretty cool.

Overall, 9/10, would get ♥♥♥♥♥ by mutant cannibals again.

The Forest is a great survival/horror Game!

This Game is about you and your journey to find your son, who got kidnapped
from a Tribe of really mad natives.
Also Cannibals are on your Butt and try to eat your legs!
The Building-System is pretty good eventough there are bugs here and there,
but thats not a Problem because the Game is constantly getting updated.
The Developers even did the feature to show the exact time when the Update is coming out.
This can be seen on the bottom left corner of the menu ingame.

The Game is still in early acces so if bugs or glitches happen, the developers will fix it soon!

So all in all this is a Great Survival game and is worth a try.
In my opinion its one of my favourite survivalgame, because it's a survival game we have not seen yet.
If you take DayZ, H1Z1, Rust or any other survival game then you will see its not that hard, but in this game
it's different! You are constantly focused and ready to react quick, because the natives are on you and watch you!

The Co-op mode is a lot of Fun!
But you should play it with friends and not play on an online server, the other players can annoy some times.
In multiplayer there are some bugs, but those are not critical.

The Story isn't really there yet. It's still in development.

Everyone who is interested in a good survival game has to try! :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From having only played an hour so far, I would say that this game has a lot of potential. Many features in the game are quite simplistic, such as the crafting menu and your player's inventory. There's almost no hassle when using them, and you won't get confused. The only bad thing about the crafting is that once you place a blueprint down, you can't remove it to build somewhere else (at least I haven't found a way to yet).

The atmospheric tone of the game is excellent. It's very dark and creepy, especially if you venture into the cave systems. The lighting is well done, both inside the caves and outside, and the sounds are simply brilliant. The mutants/tribesmen--whatever they actually are--add a more ominous element to the game, and they work surprisingly well early on in the game's stage.

If you're a fan of survival games, The Forest is definitely for you. You can get a spear and use it to go fishing, or just run around with it attacking things like a madman. Aside from fish, I've only seen lizards and rabbits so far as a food source, as well as energy bars.

There are quite a few bugs that I've noticed while playing, but that is to be expected in alpha. Certain objects, namely some rocks and containers, have no mass and you can walk straight through them. Some tools, such as the second axe you find in the game, can be replicated repeatedly. I had amassed a large stack of them at my camp by accident while switching to other tools. I wouldn't worry too much about the bugs right now. The development team of this game seems very promising, and I have the utmost faith that they will fix them to the best of their abilities.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game to any survival or horror fanatic.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy friend and I load into game. We spend 10 minutes throwing tennis balls at eachother. It's getting late, let's get serious. We set down the foundation for a cabin and start collecting logs. We complete it the next morning after making a poorly made tent to sleep the night away. We're both starving. I suggest hunting Bambi. The land is rich with wildlife. The first deer I approach runs off at around 50 mph straight off a cliff, leading into the ocean... The second runs in circles, taunting me, it knows how exausted I am. It's confident in it's abilities, but I however am not. We spend the rest of the day hunting, but to no avail. I suggest a new approach. I have one bottle of liquor. I make a molotov. Things get intense. We approach a deer, we're in a bit of a rush, this is murder" I said.  My friend replied saying it was what we had to do to survive. I feel my throat getting dry. I grip the molotov
date: I take a breath... I throw it at the deer. The bottle crashes against the deer
recommended: hitting it in the head. The deer stops
hoursPlayed: dazed
voteText: and runs away. My friend and I stare at eachother in silence. I forgot to light the molotov.\n\nThus ends our first play of Forest."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you want a game where you can:

1. Reenact the Malaysian Airlines Incident
2. Run Incessantly From Hordes of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Naked Men
3. Work nonstop

Then The Forest is your game.

Join your friends in the super awesome multiplayer, and build awesome things like, giant bonfires, dead body piles, and simple shelters. Though your starting supplies are somewhat primitive, you can use you Engineering Skills that seemingly come from nowhere to master the art of bushcraft and IED making.

Having problems with Naked Men at night? Blow them up a la Al-Habeeb by putting bombs in their heads and throwing them at the little chromosome deficients. There's also a boat.

11/10 Would Play

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having crashed my plane on a remote island, I find myself standing alone in the rain.  I find an axe and proceed to chop down enough trees to be able to construct a small, crude shelter and a fire.  I then busy myself setting snare traps to deter any unsavory people from invading my home.  As I examine my traps, I am unsettled to find a friendly tribesman strung up in one of my snares, much to the horror of his two comrades.  Being the gentleman that I am, and wanting to show that I mean these fine men no harm, I free the distressed man by severing his legs.  He flops around for a bit before lying completely still; I take this as a sign that he is relieved.  My act of good faith seems to have further upset the two mobile tribesmen, and it comes to my attention that perhaps good deeds mean less to them then combat prowess.  Still desperate to prove my worth, I step forward and begin to swing my axe in a wonderful display of weapon mastery.  I may have impressed them too much, as they run towards me in an attempt to get a closer look at my beautiful axemanship.  They run directly into the path of my axe before they, too, fall over and cease to move.  I am deeply upset at the unfortunate accident, and I wonder if perhaps there were other members of these men's tribe who will miss them.  I begin to set up a memorial using the limbs and heads of the deceased and light it ablaze; a true warrior's funeral.  In minutes, I find myself surrounded by tribesmen and women, who are presumably here to mourn their fallen comrades.  I kneel before my effigy, a sign that I was honored to know these men.  A young woman steps forward from the group and looks at the burning pyre; I can only assume that she is the wife of one of the dead warriors.  I still have one of the men's arms, and I attempt to present her with it to remember her husband.  I tap her on the head with the stiff hand.  She turns slowly and looks at me with sad eyes.  The entire crowd goes crazy.  They pounce on me.  I am torn asunder like wet toilet paper in a firing range.
11/10, would hold crazy native funeral again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. It is so realistic made forest. You begin on the plane with your son and suddently your plane crashes to island with mutants and canninbals. The canninbal takes the child and your goal is to save him, but as you begin to explore and survive you begin to face the mutants, canninbals, weather changes...
You can built an awesome bases around the crashed plane, on forest, on mountains, on beach and even in caves (BEWARE: Each time you save or spawn there, the mutants an canninbals will spawn too. If you build your base right between where canninbals have camps, then expect to have attacks, they will come everytime). Also making traps against canninbals is sweet idea, so you can protect yourself against them and finished them with normal or modern axe.
I gaved three copies to my friends and we created a lot of bases and traps but theres more to explore :3

Yes the game is in alpha stage, so expect some funny or weird bugs for example like:

- Throwing TNT on the ground around 5 trees and suddently 10 more trees fall down but in the end you get a lot of logs,
- Canninbals no clipping through trap when the trap isnt activated,
- When you chop down the tree, few logs launch into air high,
- Spider Mutant or Armsy Mutant destroys one part of your base but can accidently destroy other side of your base somehow,
- Trying to hit canninbals while they just stand and you somehow get hitted once or twice.

Me and my friends are enjoying this game so much because its fun and open world and exploring so much new things.
And in every update this game gets better and better.

If you love forest and exploring on adventure to find and built stuff, you should get this game right now :D
Keep it up developers, you did an amazing job on this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The entire reason I began PC Gaming was because of DayZ. Well that game is horrible compared to The Forest, and it makes up for the disappointment DayZ gave me. My friend and I play this game a good amount together and when you think you've seen it all, this game has even more to throw at you.

Pros:
- Fight Cannibals with Cannibalism
- Crafting System
- Dynamic Weather
- You'll get Sp00ked
- Player has the Choice to End the Game
- Custom Housing
- Treetop Communities are Possible
- Burn People Alive with a Flare Gun
- Jumping into a Giant Sinkhole and losing everything - or nothing

Cons:
- Hunting a Deer makes you feel like a Monster when you kill it (It Cries)
- Alligators/Crocodiles are Scarier than Sharks
- Dynamite Explosion is a 4/10
- Trees Explode when they fall (Leaves and Branches could get an animation for when Trees Fall)
- The 4-8 legged 16 armed creatures will be in your nightmares
- Sharks spawn on the beach in Multiplayer (You Can't Hunt Them)

Overrall this is a great game for PC gamers who enjoy any genre of games, except maybe MOBAs, cause, no elements of that are in this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those of you who don't want to read a load of text, then here is my short snippet of me playing this game.
http://youtu.be/mMNDEOcIyrg

For those who want what i think of the game then keep reading!

I started off in the forest crashing in the plane, my son next to me. This ended up after the crash with one of the cannibals appearing infront of me with my child.
He runs away and you are alone, other than a few rabbits.
So i pick up my axe and get ready to chop some tree's, i chop away and the whole tree come tumbling down, showering the floor with logs. I then check out my survival guide and am told to build a shlelter, i select it and get ready place it, to which i get attacked from behind and dragged into a cave.

I open my eyes to see nothing but dead people and heads on sticks, it's dark, i'm lost and creeped out!

The forest is so far a wonderfully creepy game, i wouldn't say a horror game in the sense you will be scared (at least for me).
However you will constantly be on your toes, wondering what each and every noise is. You will be building your house and see people suddenly around you climbing the trees.
The atmosphere is superb.
The graphics are very nice too, considering this is an indie game in alpha i am VERY impressed.
The sounds are a little bat at times, when the plane crashes it doesn't feel like there was much going on. The child is just sitting there not making a noise and so was i. Although this is most likely and alpha thing and there will be more when the game is more complete.

Overall i would say even now in an alpha state this game is very muhc worth it's price as it captures what it is trying to do so well. Not to mention it will only get better and better, to which i assure you all this game will be extremely good when complete.

If you like to be scared, if you like to survive then pick this up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pure innovative genius! It sucks you in from the start with a realistic plane crash, a mysterious island, and some weird naked dude who likes to sneak up on me while I'm chopping down trees. I decided to kill him...not the best idea I've ever had, as later that night while  I was snuggled up by my campfire, his buddies decided to show up. Now I understand this game is in alpha, but holy hell it's fantastic. The bad guys are fast moving, calculative creeps who won't give up. You can interact fully with the environment around you, and pretty much build an epic survival compound.

Sure, there are bugs, but not many that I've seen. The worst of it is there's a bloody table that seems to haunt my camp. It has a life of its own as it floats around and crashes into my house. No problem! everything else so far seems to be working fine.

So Jump in, immerse yourself and see how long you can survive. I think I've made it to about day 10 right now, and my fortress in impenetrable. I hope...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i3-4150, EVGA 750ti Superclocked mini ITX system.
Resolution: 1920x1080
Average framerate:40-60fps Max settings (Bloom off), 50-60+FPS Medium settings.
Graphics settings: High-Max Settings
Average framerate: 50-60FPS
Input device used: Mouse and Keyboard.

**Note** Put Terrain setting on High(Parallax Occlusion) even if you're running at low or medium settings. The terrain looks much, much more realistic while barely affecting performance and framerate.

I bought this game last year and recently started playing it again. I actually just bought a copy for my brother so that we could play coop. Let me just start by saying that this is a mixed review, though I will be giving it a thumbs up because it's improved tremendously since last May.

Pros:

-The Cannibal AI seem to be much more intelligent and unpredictable than the last time I played. They chase you on all fours very quickly, seem to get used to burning effigies, and always seem to thwarth your plans at remaining safe.
-There seems to be a few more animals and the crafting system is a little more polished.
-The graphics and graphical options and presets are much more diverse.
-The addition of co-op is amazing. Though it definitely needs more work, after playing for a few hours with my brother we came to the conclusion that the devs must put more focus on this aspect of the game.

What I'd like to see in coop gameplay:

-Sharing and giving items between players.
-When hosting a game, the player I invited always spawns back to the plane after they die. I load at my last save point, see player 2 flash quickly, and they then reappear at the plane.
-When a player puts meat on the drying rack, I don't see it. He doesn't see my meat. There is also a bug when we both make a log sleigh or carry cannibal bodies: They are invisible.
-A bunkbed system in which the two players fall asleep at the same time. The lack of sleep in co-op is sort of unrealistic. I'd say maybe have it so that each player has to press a key within 5 seconds so that they can all fall asleep simultaneously and wake up at the same time.
-When I host a game, I see a wild boar, but the other player sees a deer. This doesn't break the game, but it's quite a funny bug.
-Knives. It's almost weird that they're not included in the game. They could be used to improve and/or upgrade tools and also as a weapon.
-We aren't 100% certain of this, but we're pretty sure the cannibal/mutants seem to be less frequent and perhaps dumbed down" in coop?
- Rechargeable Crank flashlight?

I am aware that the game is still in Early Access
date: but I will mention this: The developers are listening to the community and are actively working on the game. They have a very detailed list of their fixes on their website and I will say with confidence that this is probably the best early access title I've played
recommended: especially for the price that it's selling for."

I dont normally do any reviews of any game, because i simply dont care, but, when you encounter certain games that you really enjoy you feel compelled to do so

The only thing that i would add to the game its more objectives, more things to do around, or for example, that depending of how many days you have survived you start getting waves and waves of mutants, it should get harder to survivee and MOST OF ALL, what i would like to see its a hardcore mode on mutiplayer that if you die or anyone dies 2 times, you permanently die or at least are unable to spawn until 1 day or something like that, because the fact that you simply respawn on the plane takes away the danger element and the vulnerability of the game, you dont really fear dying since you know you just respawn and thats it.

Make it more challenging and to horribly fear death and losing everything, a game that once everyone dies, the save game erase itself, there must always be 1 survivor to make your friends re spawn in some hours again, i know the concept seems hard to understand but all i want its to really fear the forest and surviving, and not just harvest wood until i get bored of building stuff.

Keep up the good work and let me know about your thoughs of a hardcore mode

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Forest is a survival horror game that actually does survival horror right, from the sound to how everything looks, Thats why I instantly fell in love with The Forest, the immersion. If you have ever played the Silent Hill series, you would know of how good a job it makes you feel like you're alone, but not ALONE. And that is what seperates The Forest from the rest of the zombie" survival "horror" games
date: it gets rid of the generic zombie foe that you don't mind putting a couple rounds into and gives you a native cannibalistic tribe that may make you think before taking them out incase one of them gets away and alerts the rest of the tribe.\n\nThis game is legitimately scary
recommended: from your first sighting of the tribe searching the plane wreck to the first time you get knocked out and dragged to their cave. It's purely atmospheric horror and It doesn't just rely on cheap scare tactics like jump-scares and loud noises like other survival horror games.\n\nNow on to the survival aspect of The Forest
hoursPlayed: I personally think this part was really well done
voteText: it actually makes you adapt and survive! From not being able to eat raw meat and actually having to put it onto the fire and wait for it to cook so you don't burn it
helpfulPercent: to simply how the tree cutting animations are and finding berries that are not poisonous to eat.\n\nAt the moment it's pretty buggy. But what do you expect from a pre-alpha? I'm really looking forward to seeing what Endnight games can do with The Forest in the future. This game would easily be Game Of The Year for me
votesHelpful: normally I wouldn't even fathom choosing a game like this for GOTY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

a surprisingly good game... nice graphics (Unity Engine!)

an outstanding smart enemy AI:

the Engine will spawn more enemies and enemy types per ingame day as a bonus to the normal cannibal/mutant/tribal people enemies. --- they will not attack you when they are not starving! you can try a coexistence and stay hidden for a long time. UNTIL you begin to harvest the forest. those woods are holy for them.

ressources are respawning very fast and there are a few story-secrets, hidden OP weapons and hidden settlements of those tribal people out there in a big map.

Player buildings are great and can be expanded to a real Fortress.

there is a pro and a contra to this game: no tutorial at all. (which makes the first run impossible!) ...but crafting is more intuitive like this. (there is a forest crafting wiki) The player has to find out most recipes by just combining and trying. This brings immersion to crafting and makes you proud of your new upgraded spear or your personally crafted bow! (if you try it without the wiki of course.)

enemies are weak overall... blocking is not op and will harm the player for 10-20% of unblocked dmg. BUT the AI hits like a truck. you can take 3-4 attacks from a normal guy and it is over. GREAT! this makes combat easy but also very rewarding! (the enemy movement is really weird and will make every fight unique!)

there is no endgame! there is just an atmosphere of fear and terror for lets say 20 cool hours. if you want to build your fortress in hell. this is your game. hold out forever! ...maybe give up your fortress, lay fire and flee on your boat... maybe you will find a cave and live there... just to find out it is THEIR CAVE! :)

If they can get you 2 times at zero HP, they will cook and eat you half alive! you got only 2 lives.

dynamite, molotovs, a bow, spears, axes, katanas, lizard-skin-underpants for armor... a crown of leaves to be the stealthed bow sniper... or just be the naked axemurderer who invades them, hanging the heads of their leaders in the middle of their settlement. BECOME THE LEGEND! paint your face with mud and await them! Pure Freedom in Unity 5 Beauty!

...or hide like me every day in a different cave after you saw what they did to your friends and how powerful their magic is.

10/10 --- Naked ♥♥♥♥-Demons trying to eat you and your friends in multiplayer in an excellent immersive sound and graphic atmosphere while your sanity meter reaches zero and nobody out there in ours or in their world knows what the effects of this meter are!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A friend of mine bought this on Early Access. I, myself, was a bit skeptical of buying games that are still in development, but after watching my friend, I was sold on the game. This game is brimming with potential and it's only in pre-Alpha. I cannot even imagine what the finished product will look like.

This game is sure to pull you in with the atmosphere it creates, the gameplay, graphics and sound effects it presents. With this game, you'll end up spending hours constructing your perfect fort, hunting animals and killing cannibals. And the fact, that it gets updated with new features, about every month, is sure to maintain your confidence in this project, if not bolster it. More than worth the money I paid.

Crazy fun game.

I started playing 3 days ago. I was playing co-op with 2 other friends. On our 1st play through we built a pretty large base with double high stone walls surrounding our buildings and a pond on top of a cliff near the sea. We also had a small retaining wall further out from our base. As our base grew larger and we cut down more tress and we attracted more cannibals. On the 4th night it was pure chaos. We were hit by multiple raiding parties and than some of the larger mutants appeared and starting wrecking our base. The attack went all night and we eventually died to the mutants. We re-spawned but the mutants would not leave the vicinity.

After that crazy battle we decided to start a new co-op game as we felt we learned a lot from the 1st experience.

Words can not describe how creepy this game can get. I always play videos game in the a darken room. This game, I always have the lights on.  Some of the sounds you can hear out in the forest at night are bone chilling. The Devs did a great job creating an intense and scary atmosphere in this game.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all my plane crash lands in the middle of god knows where. Some Hippy takes the boy I acquired pre-flight and runs off with the little swine. I paid good money for that child!

Next I decide I better make the most out of the experience and pick up some of the islands finest sticks and stones. I come across a small settlement of tents by the waters-edge.

Hoping to avoid an invitation to one of their terrible music festivals, I scattered on and set up a small shelter and fire further down the line. However just as one might expect, the fire attracted more Hippies.

They watched me in confusion for some time, obviously never having seen a person next to a fire without a guitar before. More of them arrived and began getting aggressive. They must have misplaced their marijuana, and immediately painted the blame on the outsider. Clearly simple conversation was too advanced for these dirty, naked, smelly rascals.

I awoke in a cave, joined by a good deal of deceased individuals who clearly staged a mass suicide after having given up on humanity, and not enjoying the taste of their rather strange smelling brownies. Armed with my new friend, Jibbly Jabb the lighter, I made my way out of the cave and back towards my camp, which was only a short distance away.

I lasted another 2 minutes back at camp before I was unfairly and unexpectedly pummelled to death by Boob-Hippy and Winkie-Doodle.

Despite the natives' lack of clothing and proper etiquette, I thoroughly enjoyed my romp in this land and anxiously await my triumphant and vengeful return.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

'The Forest' has a way to go but for a game still in Alpha it promises a rich, scary survival experience. The island is beautiful, not only sporting a lushious overworld but also a dank cavernous system underground filled with nightmarish creatures. Not to say that you are safe above ground either as packs of cannibal clans roam the forest, searching for their next meal. Unless you get your act together and locate a secure position in which to begin constructing your camp then that meal might be you.

The AI of the cannibals is quite simply disturbing. I am not usually unnerved by computer AI but these guys will hunt you, taunt you and test your resolve before either retreating (probably to tell others where you are) or closing in for the kill.

The crafting system is nice, combining various objects in order to create tools or weapons to help you survive. The building system seems solid however there's not a lot to play with at the moment. The ability to place your own foundations and build a shelter of your design is in there, but not quite working just yet (at least in my experience it has been a bit buggy).

All in all well worth buying if you are into survival gaming. As previously mentioned it has a long way to go but for what it is in alpha 'The Forest' is well worth your prolonged attention.
voteText: 18 of 21 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off there may be two reasons for you not to buy this game right now. The first one being it's Alpha and has PLENTY of bugs which can really ruin the immersion and excitement you get during your first playthrough and in my opinion that's a pretty big deal considering this game has every element it needs to be the best (Horror) Survival game of the year. Secondly you MUST have a good computer to run this game or it will be 15 dollars down the drain, If you can't run Rust then forget about getting this game as of now and start investing in one that can run this future Masterpiece of a game.

When I first started playing this game I felt a rush of excitement and fear as I did when I played Minecraft for the first time, (These games are very different but have a similiar concept, to survive and craft) This game is intense already to say the least, but again the fact it's in Alpha and has many bugs can ruin that.

If you want the best experience for this game when you first play I suggest waiting a few weeks

If you want to help support the developers of this and be a part of the games journey to it's finished product then buy this, you won't regret it.


Gotta give this game a 8/10

Things to keep in mind when you're actually playing this:
1. Use the Axe to break open suitcases, good loot and food in there
2. Take advantage of the stealth mechanic and listen for the noises Cannibals make, you'll probably know it when you hear it
3. If you are killed by cannibals and taken to their cave, YOU MUST get the flare gun inside the room you wake up in, don't leave it without it because you'll most likely need it to escape and it has plenty of ammo
4. And above all, have fun


Happy hunting

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been really interested in the open-world survival genre, and purchased a few of the popular early release games. I tried a lot of the ones that focus on MMO-type gameplay, and quicky became bored with them. I can only walk around for so long starving to simply get shot by some guy with a cowboy hat as soon as he sees me.

I finally decided to try out the The Forest, and it's the first one of the genre that I've been thoroughly impressed by. With an indie team of 3 devs, the game has a surprisingly polished look and feel. It creates the creepy atmosphere it's going for perfectly. I'm writing this review after my first night of playing, and I've only played co-op so far, so I can strongly recommend playing with a friend (but I'm sure playing alone would be just as satisfying and probably more creepy).

I already have come to love the building system. Rather than punching trees endlessly, you design out your building initially and it shows you what resources you need to collect to complete the structure. You then go out to find those resources. It's amazing how much more immersive the game is when the tree actually falls and you carry a few logs back at a time to your shelter-in-progress.

Had a great time after my first few hours, and I can't wait to get a little more confident to explore the more dangerous parts of the forest.
voteText: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After the massive sellout directionless flop that was Minecraft survival mode, which spawned an uncountable number of voxel survival clones, came the wave of zombie survival games of which there was an equal number with a disappointing lack of variety. The survival genre needed something fresh. Something that was survival, without the endless additions of survival mechanics, but with enough elements remaining that the game remained fun and challenging. Something that had the wonder and danger of exploration, with the terror of creatures in the night, without taking itself too seriously or not seriously at all. And something without zombies, but something that could instill just as many fears and nightmares if not more.

Enter: The Forest

It's worth noting that The Forest was the first game on Steam to really start the stranded survival" genre
date: and there are many games out there currently "inspired" by its formula including Stranded Deep
hoursPlayed: Savage Lands

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been keeping an eye on the Forest since it's launch earlier this year and really loved the premise behind it.  Game videos looked cool, and even after playing it there seems like there is a metric crap ton of potential.

Early Access is always a dice roll and I'm pulling for these guys, but I just can't recommend the game yet.  Looking beyond completely expected bugginess, with less than 25 total recipes to craft, I didn't feel a sense of progression.  After spending almost 2 hours building defensive walls and venturing out to do some exploirng I really didn't see much else to do.

If development continues along this path I can see this being an outstanding game in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: I've crashed on some godforsaken island. Woke up covered in blood, brink of starvation and barely alive. I made it to my feet and looted the plane for goods. Nothing much, couple meals and some soda. Even found some booze which I've kept for later. Staggered outside to the site of a picturesque forest full of wildlife. I borrowed an axe from a stewardess who didn't look like she'd be needing it, and started hacking open some luggage. Didn't find much, some cloth and some granola bars. I headed out and ended up at a coast, which I followed for a while. Found some cargo containers with some circuit boards and a bunch of asprin. I took it all. Went further down and found a crashed Yacht, so I'm thinking this is somewhere in the ♥♥♥♥in' Bermuda triangle. Found some flares on that, and some rope. Headed inland but got lost, ended up at some small village with triangular buildings. Lots of dead people...some I recognized from my flight. Found a better axe buried in a tree, and more soda than I'll ever need in my life, as well as some dynamite. Headed in I think a northerly direction, found another village. Managed to kill a couple rabbits and lizards, made a small pouch for berries and glued some leaves onto the lizard skin and wore it for camo. I literally ran into some savage on accident. It ran away, laughing. Shaken, I kept heading down the hill and found some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who looked like someone had run a sword through him. I took it. Katana, very nice. Kept heading that direction and found a small pond with a tent next to it. Found a cooking pot and a spear. It was getting dark and I was hungry and thirsty, so I quickly made a small shelter out of sticks and leaves as well as a tiny fire, got some water out of the pond and boiled it, drank that and cooked my rabbits. Put out the fire and slept through the night.


Day 2: Woke up early and got out of there. Walked for a long time and got lost a bunch. Ran into another savage. He rushed me, so I sliced him with the katana, but the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ was just a diversion as two more jumped me from behind. I managed to take all three down but I was hurting pretty bad, so I took some asprin and that cleared it up. Kept going and ended up back at the guy who'd been run through. Noticed there was a cave behind him, so I started going through it. I haven't been using my lighter at all, even though I explored about half of last night. Hard as hell to see but I didn't want to attract any attention. In the cave, I only used my lighter when I couldn't tell where I was going, or to check for side passages. I found a fork in the road and went left, and found another fork. Went left again and found four human heads on the ground, still decaying. Past that was some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a Bible and a crucifix in his hand. Head looked to have been eaten off, possibly while he was still alive. Dead end past that. Headed back and was greeted with a wooden wall, with a skull hanging over it, a candle in each eye. Unnerved, I cut down the wall and found another one. Cut that one down and there was a massive open chasm past that. I heard some very loud footsteps, like a giant was walking around. To my left I saw two...things. The light was bad, but they looked like two massive pillars of flesh with about ten arms apiece. Keeping in my scream was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. I scrambled past them and found a climbing rope, and descended. It was very wet down here, and I was doing my best not to slip and drown. Kept going and there was another, even bigger chasm. I took one step inside and the most terrifying sound I've ever heard in my life pierced my ears. It sounded like babies crying, but it was too high pitched, too...alien. I stumbled inside and saw big tents in one corner, which was where the crying was coming from. I crouched down and went over, and sure enough there were deformed babies twitching and crying on the rock floor, a humanoid standing over them, hunched, apparently asleep. Surrounding them in a ring were big rocks, one of which I was hiding behind, and on those wooden crates. I cut one open but nothing was inside. I quickly moved away, but to my horror the babies lunged at me. I cut them down, whimpering, trying not to make any noise to awake anything in here. I ran as fast as I could away from them, flicking my lighter on to guide the way. I went down a passage that ended in a rope. I quickly grabbed on and climbed up, hoping this was the exit. It ended much too soon, and I pulled myself up and sprinted down the passage. To my utter terror, it ENDED. There was nothing, just a blank wall and a skull with a candle in it. I slowly turned back, towards the sounds of piercing baby cries and the wind passing through the damp, cold cave. I sank to the ground in defeat, and await death.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My personal thoughts on this extraordinary indie game:
As the lone survivor of a passenger jet crash, you find yourself in a mysterious forest battling to stay alive against a society of cannibalistic mutants. Build, explore, survive in this terrifying first person survival horror simulator.


Welcome to The Island. A Indie survival-horror game, and a pretty one too! You will find yourself easily immersed in The Forest's world, a world crafted with much care and dedication. Animations are greatly done, while the simple act of chopping down a tree can be a fun experience, since visuals are splendid in this game. But this isn't everything this game has to offer, we have a pretty big island full with stuff to see, from cannibal camps, tortured survivor, abandoned camps and caves. Gameplay wise we have a few factors and mechanics, you need to gather,hunt for food, build a shelter, build fire places to light up during the night, hide indoors when it rains and many, many others.

The cannibals are nicely designed, and you will find yourself interested in their background since they aren't your standard zombies" unlike the other thousand of games with the same setting. The crafting part of the game is still basic

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Forest is one of the many survival games you will find in early access. But in my opinion this is not one of the terrible ones. It has constant updates making the game better all the time, for example co-op just came out! But this is not only a survival game, it’s also horror. When you explore them caves for the first time with your little lighter that keeps going off you will be scared. Really scared.

Enemies
The enemies are not zombies. Yes, you heard a survival game with NO zombies! This has mutants. The mutants are very well made and will take different approaches towards you, for example one mutant on its own tends to run off. It will then come back with its friends. They also attack in turns a lot. One will attack then pull back and another will try to hit you. They climb trees to ambush you and will also try to flank you. In the deepest caves you will find the really terrifying ones. These ones are proper mutants.

Survival
You will need to eat, drink, keep your energy up, keep your health up and build a shelter. You will also be defending yourself against mutants while doing all of that. To survive you need to hunt, fish, scavenge camps, chop trees and fight.  You will need to hunt and fish to eat and keep your energy and health up. You will need to scavenge camps for items you can craft and also for food. You will need to chop trees to build a shelter, create traps, and more. You will need to fight so you don’t die.

Environment
The environment is amazing! From the forest its self with the high trees to the sandy beaches scattered with camps.  No matter where you are, you won’t feel safe. You will need to use the environment to help you survive.  The forest has the trees you need for the camp. Around the beaches you will find more rocks. In the caves you will find better equipment. Just remember the caves are home to the mutants.

Co-op!
I’ve played co-op with one friend, and in my opinion it made the game much better. It does make the game easier but it feels much better knowing you have a friend watching your back while you make a shelter. Right now co-op is full of bugs but I’m sure they will disappear one by one as the developers improve the game.

I hope you enjoyed reading this review as I did enjoy writing it!

So for a not completed game, the Forest is pretty awesome.

First Playthrough
Crash land in a forest, build a fire, vainly try to feed fire, build a shelter. Shelter gets built and there's my friendly neighbor dropping by. So I do the sensible thing and hit him with an axe, he knocks me out and drags me to a cave where I'm killed by weird Octo Mutants.

Second Playthrough
Vainly try to build a bonfire on a small island, slowly die from hunger until nightfalls and I'm massacred by the enemy.

Third Playthrough (Co-Op!)
Join some random players much, much better than me in building a camp, they mainly build, I chase flaming rabbits. Daytime comes and they go into the cave, I'm at the camp until the cannibal crew arrives, where I promptly haul ♥♥♥ straight to the cave to meet my pro players. I am once again killed by OctoMutants.

All in all, great game, good creepy atmosphere especially on singleplayer and the co-op's a nice touch. Still a but off feeling at times, especially with chopping down trees but I definitely recommend!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is worth noting that I have been highly anticipating the release of 'The Forest' alpha since the release of the initial trailer.

Having played the game for a short period of time, I can already tell just how well the team has married the immersion and fun-factor.

The game is pretty damned terrifying already. One minute, I'm spearing fish in a crystal clear pond without a care in the world and next I hear an array of strange animal sounds. As the rain begins to fall, I direct my attention to the source of the noise and spot a patrolling party of around 10 tribal figures in the distance. However they seem unaware of my presence and march away into the overgrowth. Around a minute later, after I begin picking up essentials from the corpses strewn around a camp located right next to my own, the cannibals burst out of the foliage ahead of me, chasing me down, surrounding me and eventually killing me.

It's worth noting that the AI and animations in this game are significantly better than I expected they would be. One of the cannibals darted ahead of me from the side, abruptly skidding to a halt and preventing my escape while another realistically hopped from tree bark to tree bark above.

In regards to the crafting and resource gathering, I haven't experimented too much but it seems fairly straightforward and that's not a bad thing at all. Approaching and hacking down a small plant will provide you with branches and leaves and hacking down an entire tree will provide you with logs to carry which you can store in a log holder if you've crafted one. Creating a fire and shelter are essential and the fact that you have to apply leaves to the fire to keep it going adds to the realism. Overall, the crafting is fairly immersive and skinning an animal and then picking the meat up and directly applying it to the fire all seem pretty damned seamless.

The lighting seems quite advanced as well and the cavern segments remind me of the film, 'The Descent' in a good way, with the ambient sounds of water drops, stalactites, stalagmites, water reflections and numerous crystal groups.

All this being said, the game is in early alpha state and there are quite a few bugs which is to be expected during this stage, wherein the player can clip through certain objects and swapping equipped items can sometimes result in weird overlapping objects but overall, I believe that this game is easily worth the price tag and I eagerly look forward to the development in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I like this game, but it needs some work. By buying this game you should take into consideration you're purchasing a 'Beta' version, you won't get a completed game (yet) and there will be bugs.

The Basics
Having that said I really do enjoy this game, it's difficult, but not impossible, it's challenging, but never too unfair, surely there is quite a few bugs to be polished out of the way but that's why it's in beta. The idea is simple, gather some wood, craft some better tools, survive the night. It's more difficult than it sounds though and you will be facing numerous challenges; hypothermia, hunger, fatigue and of course cannibals.

The Gameplay
Gameplay wise this game needs some fixing, there's a few bugs when chopping down trees or mashing enemies in the face with a club fashioned out of a stick and someone's skull, not all hits will register and it can become a bit frustrating. Once you've learned to deal with these little things the game is pretty polished.
It's pretty easy to get a nice structure going, and it won't be long until you have yourself a nice base, just don't forget to make a fire.

With the new added in co-op feature this game becomes a LOT more enjoyable, it's double the fun when you're running around with some friends collectively hacking limbs off cannibals, and I think it's a great addition to the game. In fact, just the fun you could have in the co-op is probably worth buying this game.

The Graphics
This game looks pretty, the shadow bugs present in previous versions (your character having hollowed out eyes and neck in your shadow) are now fixed and I can't really think of any way to complain about the graphics in this game, it's imply outstanding. The world feels alive and immersive.

To Summarize
+ Great gameplay.
+ Co-Op is a blast!
+ World feels immersive, with attention to detail.
+ It's a challenge, but not unfair.
- Minor bugs.

Thank you for reading :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Recommendation based strictly on the fact that the developer has a pre-release game with a countdown timer to the next major update that has yet to see the ball be dropped on.

Content updates have been steady, and it's come a long way from the glitch fest the early alphas were. Still has longer to go until all the content in, but this is one of the three foremost examples of a good pre-release program I can think of (others being Minecraft and Don't Starve).

I'm not going to go on about the gameplay - standard survival stuff, but first person. A lot of fun, in my opinion, though I kind of like the zen experience of staying on the overworld and avoiding cannibals while I live a quiet version of Castaway. Has a lot of promise, and a lot of current content if you enjoy building and hunting and general survival stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the few early access games that I have faith in.

The Forest is more than just a game for me, after visiting Yellowstone National Park in upstate Wyoming, I could really compare the seemingly cold-ish forest environment to The Forest because the devs in my opinion have changed so much since v0.01 to make it FEEL like you're in the forest. They work with graphics and just amazing sound. The environment feels so natural that I don't want to even be interupted when playing this game, because it's THAT GOOD!

Starting from the beginning plane crash, the 1 minute-or-so intro is better than my 48 hours on DayZ, and is more interesting. On top of that the devs nailed the in-flight ambience, me just recently flying on a two hour plane to Chicago it was something to truly compare. When the plane splits into thirds the sounds of seperation deeply add to the immersion, I'm already wrapped into the game before even playing this thriller.

On the surface, the atmosphere and environment is very well-done. I especially like stepping out for heavy winds blowing through the forest. At night the sound of cannibals screaming in the distance can also put one to a shiver. Cave environments are even more scary. The devs did so by adding fantastic ambience sounds and lots, and lots, of props that I won't spoil here.

Also, the reason that this is the only early-access game I have faith in, is because the devs, number one, let you know when the next update is, and they have a suggestion thread which they RESPOND to! This way, you can look forward to the next update and really see what the devs are doing, and how the work well. I actually think my grandkids would be able to play a sequel to a sequel, to a sequel, etc. Because the development rate and consistency is so good. The devs have a LOT OF POTENTIAL HERE! DON'T RUIN IT!

You may not like this, but the amount of content in this game, the amount of fun I've had in my -so far- 21 hours, is worthy of at least a 30$ game if not 40$.

By realease, if the devs don't screw up you could be looking at a 50$ game. This game could be like Alien: Isolation, I say this because they've gotten a base for sound, environment, and horror. They just need to do more.

I rate this game, as of this state, an 11/10, especially for being a trusty early-access. WITH CO-OP! Another pro!
Truly a fantastic experience and I expect myself to continue to play it for a long time.

Early Access Review

Early Access Review, 04/19/2015

I do not by any means consider myself an expert on The forest, but so far my experience has been a blast! I have played this game multiplayer with my brother, cousin, and a few friends, and have (somewhat scantily) Followed the development of the game. The Ambience is skillfully done, the artwork looks amazing, and the gameplay, while still being in early access, is still enjoyable. I have been dinking around in this game off and on for the past few months, and have seen a HUGE improvement in the entire system, with the addition of new recipes, new mobs, new entities, better systems, etc... I know that a lot of Early Access games have turned out to be huge disappointments, but so far, this game has been meeting, if not exceeding Expectations. Developers, you should be proud of yourselves, for the progress you have been making, and while I don't know how much that means to you, I'd like to think that it means a lot coming from me. This game will probably turn out to be something absolutely amazing, and I think that the developers have a great game going on. I definately reccomend this game, and do not regret buying it while it is still in Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Birds!! BIRDS!!!

Birds everywhere! Swing your axe randomly... kill a bird... chop down a tree... accidently kill a bird, light a fire, suicidal bird kills itself in fire,  Walk around ... try to rid the area of birds, unsuccessfully. Try to bargain with birds, plead with the birds, give up quit game and have nightmares about birds.

If you love birds, this is THE game for you, otherwise, pass on this until full release.

Recommended for bird lovers everywhere.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Forest is a great start out survival horror game. Stuck on an island with crazed cannibals hunting you down, you must survive in the primitive sense. Kill or be killed. The developers have thought about this quite well, ensuring tension but also allowing the player enough time to source survival stuff (wood for fires, fish for food, etc) to create their own journey. I have thoroughly enjoyed playing it so far, and though it is limited due to it's early access nature, I certainly think this game has large potential. Crafting items, buidling your own safe-haven and fighting to the death the creatures that lurk on the island is by far a true survival experience. This game reminds me very much of Lord of the Flies" book

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Too busy playing, no time to write full review yet - must have more.

I cannot begin to say how much I love this game.

Even the main menu music is reminiscent of the original Halo.  So simple, so beautiful.  That also describes the game.

Buy it.  Even at full price it is a bargain.  The content already existing provides tons of gameplay if you enjoy exploration vs. Hack and Slash.

Even at v0.22 alpha, this has more content than more expensive games. and this is all without a distracting story line.

The objective is simple.  Find your son.... but as time wears on you will begin to forget...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access review based on version 0.08. I'll keep updating this post once new versions are released.

Pros:

--- Great concept! It is really nice to see where this is going and to have a settlement with many buildings / objects is just great. As there are no objectives we are free to do whatever we wish to do. The game requires some getting used to but I like where this is going.
--- The forest itself looks gorgeous thanks to the Unity engine. The tribesmen show some great A.I. - most notable for me so far was when one of them was just injured and his friend took him away before I could perform a coup de grace. At this point this is overshadowed by the strange behaviour they show from time to time but the direction they are going is commendable.
--- Lots of things to build and to craft. And the number will (hopefully) increase greatly as the DIY / Survival guide the player utilises has a lot of empty / blurry pages.

Cons:

--- Some only noticeable once you reload the game. Either some or all the already chopped up trees simply reappear. Also, I do not mind being able to find a huge quantity of sticks and rocks but they spawn at my settlement regularly. This  is an issue in the sense that it makes gameplay much easier.
--- Some objects are floating a bit and placement of walls can be difficult at times. I installed" a wall with door and due to the surface not entirely being flat the door glitched out and started moving constantly.
--- Building rafts is not possible? I crafted one and it shot me into the air. The view was great and I survived the landing but the raft disappeared afterwards. It was pretty annoying.
--- Still lots of things to complete. There are a lot of animals - deer
recommended: turtles - but beside killing them the player cannot really do anything else.\n--- Clipping is possible close to cliffs / hills. I can easily get under some huge rocks that surround my settlement to access it more easily. They are
hoursPlayed: however
voteText:
meant to completely protect me from one side.
--- While the AI can show progress there are some strange behaviour patterns I have yet to understand.

Overall
helpfulPercent: The Forest is a great survival game and I look forward to the new updates. I really want to see this in its entirety. While not having any specific objectives / quests I want to see the option to save the protagonist's child and it would be nice to receive some guidelines from time to time as to where you are supposed to go to find some good stuff. For instance
votesHelpful: a map could be useful."
votesTotal: October 30, 2014
votesFunny: true

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNice game. At work, all I did was think about the game. As soon as I got home I played a bit. Its the sort of game that draws you back to it. The positive thing is in-game you always strive to improve. A trial and error game, which keeps you hooked. As they are adding more new stuff and updates, more content will be availabe which will increase the time spent on this game. Building your base, trying to live a sustainable life as a lone survivor surrounded by cannibals. The ideas behind the game are great and hopefully it will only get better. It can also get a bit scary.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWas building a log cabin when I was attacked by the locals. I thought they would offer to let me borrow their tools when one of them attacked me. With my trusty hatchet I killed him in self defense. Horrified in the terrible act I performed I cut off his head and made a trophy and stuck it in front of my future home. The friend of the man I murdered in self defense saw what I did and tried to claim revenge for what she witnessed. As she ran at me, she in turn ran into the burning effigy and burned to death. Understanding that she was trying to help her deceased friend I placed the trophy of her head next to her buddy. Every time I see them together I smile. I like to think that they're an the after life holding hands and picking flowers, and that they have forgiven me as their death was one of confusion and tragedy.
voteText: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful 14 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic survival game.
Three modes to play in, one without the cannibals, one where they only appear at night and the normal mode where they roam free.

The building possibilities are great, I have made several different structures. Around trees, against stone walls, around small lakes.
Many things to craft and make your survival a bit easier. Medicine, weapons, energy drinks, molotov cocktails, bombs.
Fire seems to be the best weapon against them. Burning sticks, axe or a molotov kills them instantly. If a group attacks it might be wise to flee as the cannibals have a powerful punch in their fists.

Patiently waiting for new updates

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never had so many mini heart attacks in a game before! When I first bought this game I did not expect to enjoy it so freaking much. It was all safe and good at first, just collecting a bunch of food and medicine etc., and me being so focused to hit the luggage right, I hear a creepy laugh and footsteps right behind me and I turn around fast and i jumped when I saw this creepy cannibal staring at me (felt like a staring contest for a minute there xD).

At first I thought that they weren't so bad during the day, but boy I was wrong. If you're alone and alot of them surround you, RUN FOR YOUR LIFE! xD It's hillarious playing with your friends though. We love throwing tennis balls at eachother and poking eachother with sticks XD. Had alot of fun trying to kill this spider/octopus like creature. Dying, being revived, friend dying too, both dead, wake up in the plane, run for our stuff, run around more and scream, the creature kills us again, waking up, burning that motherforker to death finally! xD

Overall, it's a really great game! You will have alot of spots to explore, creatures that will make you scream, the map is huge so you'll never get bored. I recommend it to everyone, cause it comes with the whole package: survival, scary, alot of fun. 10/10 ♥

P.S.: If you don't want to get motion sickness, make sure your motion blur is deactivated and lower your mouse sensitivity!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm an extremely large fan of survival games and by far this game has taken the cake for one of the best I've ever played. The game is visually stunning and is one of a couple games that has good looking water. You start playing and take in all the beautiful scenery and then start your fight for survival agains canibalistic mutants. I laughed when the first thing I saw was a settlement with canibals who didn't look to happy to see me.

For those who want some other ways to play the game, here are some code you can enter in the main menu of the game:
(1) vegetarianmode (Canibals only come out at night)
(2) theironforest (Makes all buildings indestructable)
(3) veganmode (Disables canibal spawning entirely)

This game has a great gameplay experience for all players new or experienced. Also, for a safer way to play, build a treehouse. It's much safer then building on the ground.

Overall a bloody awesome game.

10/10 would make a very big effigy of body parts again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

They acctually update this, no joke, an early access game with updates.
Most early access games are just cash grabs that get abandoned the moment they are put on steam, this is getting updates and fairly often. The game is challenging but fair, the graphics are occasionally buggy but when they aren't bugging out they look excelent, the gameplay (when not buggy) is fairly realistic, it's possible to survive indefinatly on the island but not easy. The ai is sometimes buggy (it's the nature of early access) but usally works well and better then some AAA games. While it needs work it is getting it, each update is noticeable. I would say 8/10 right now, as it gets more updates that should get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It’s finally here. We’ve all been so excited about it, and it finally releases.
But before you drop your hard earned money on it, know a few things. At the current time, you are unable to save. You play until you can’t play anymore, and then restart your game the next time. It doesn’t matter how far you get. Saving just doesn’t work right now. To me that is a huge part of the game considering it is a survival game, and you need to be able to save considering the expense of resources some of the crafting takes.
So purchase it at your own risk. It’s a fun game so far, but once saving is fixed, and some of the bugs are sorted it will be even better.

EDITS AS OF JUNE 17, 2014

Saving is now here! Bugs have been reduced, and overall the game feels a bit better at performance. Also, sharks have joined the plethora of creatures you can stumble upon!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bloody love this game and have had it since its original release back in 0.01. In this game you can take your creativity to the next level due to such the wide variety of things available within the survival book/building book. I've made multiple saves now making things from fortresses to nice cabins. Of course this game does have its flaws but this is obviously expected due to it being in early access. Heres my personal list of pros and cons of the game.
Pros:
Building - ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ this feature is great as this can be used for simple survival, decoration and to save you from the nasty cannibals.
Combat - This has changed ALOT over the updates but I would say the enemy AI is now considered 'intelligent' which makes the combat fair and fun.
Multiplayer - I love how this has changed since its original release it's now playable and really fun to play this game with friends and family however there are cons to this.
Exploration - It's really great to explore round this island with its great landmarks such as the boat, the numerous caves and the anchor.

Cons:
Multiplayer - There a few bad aspects to the multiplayer such as when something new that is major is released to the game it always is put onto singleplayer before they master its functionality for multiplayer.
Exploration - This does lack quite a bit as fun as it is we still have to deal with such a small enviroment also there update for the extra world space was beyond disapointing due to the broken caves and barely any new cool structures which include missing colliders in the mountain.

I hope this review helps you decide whether to purchase this game but ultimately I... RECOMMEND this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played several other similar games (Stranded Deep, Subnautica, Rising World, ARK, Life is Feudal, Long Dark, and of course Minecraft), I'm a sucker for this genre.
I saw this game about a year ago and was tempted then, but it seemed too early. Moreover, all the screenshots made it seem like this would be a very dark (literally no sunshine) game. I just recently got it, and I'm very impressed and first want to say this game is not just a night-time scary game like the pictures & intro movie suggest. Sure, it has all that, but it also has a whole world of daylight, sunshine, and good visibility.

Gameplay is beautiful and smooth for me, with lots to explore and a good deal of customization available in terms of building your base. As I mentioned, I've played several similar titles where you build a base, and I think The Forest does a really good job in terms of allowing you to place custom shapes, as well as place blueprints to visualize things before actually building. I was quite impressed by the ability to place a custom floorplan, and then automatically have walls placed around it, with the ability to toggle window/door/full wall in each section. Really well done.

Multiplayer/Co-op works great, too, but could use a little refining. I haven't found a good mechanism for hosting a dedicated server, which is somewhat limiting. There's also some instancing" issues

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played several other similar games (Stranded Deep, Subnautica, Rising World, ARK, Life is Feudal, Long Dark, and of course Minecraft), I'm a sucker for this genre.
I saw this game about a year ago and was tempted then, but it seemed too early. Moreover, all the screenshots made it seem like this would be a very dark (literally no sunshine) game. I just recently got it, and I'm very impressed and first want to say this game is not just a night-time scary game like the pictures & intro movie suggest. Sure, it has all that, but it also has a whole world of daylight, sunshine, and good visibility.

Gameplay is beautiful and smooth for me, with lots to explore and a good deal of customization available in terms of building your base. As I mentioned, I've played several similar titles where you build a base, and I think The Forest does a really good job in terms of allowing you to place custom shapes, as well as place blueprints to visualize things before actually building. I was quite impressed by the ability to place a custom floorplan, and then automatically have walls placed around it, with the ability to toggle window/door/full wall in each section. Really well done.

Multiplayer/Co-op works great, too, but could use a little refining. I haven't found a good mechanism for hosting a dedicated server, which is somewhat limiting. There's also some instancing" issues

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKeep in mind, this game is still in early access at this point, so there are bugs that need to be worked out; However, when compared to other survival games such as Rust, The Forest, offers suspense, a storyline, and beautiful graphical landscapes, from an ocean and beach setting, to cliffs, mountains and obviously a Forest. The natives who attack you have startled me many times, which makes it a creepy and fun experience to play in the dark. There is so much potential for this game, I can't wait to see where they go with it in the future. At this stage I would still recommend it and if they continue to add content, and improve upon the bugs, this may very well be one of the go-to survival games out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha v0.01 review.

Good:

-Great graphics.
-Interesting plot.
-Unique crafting.
-Potential for engaging survival environment and gameplay

Neutral:

-The A.I has potential, but behaves inconsistently. I’ve had cannibals walk right up to me and just hang out, maybe they are    just misunderstood?

Bad:

-Game performance degrades over time.
-Missing collision on some objects (various trees)
-Unlimited ammo glitch
-Pick up a single tennis ball, throw 3?
-Dead cannibal bodies explode into perfectly sliced pieces when attacked and sometimes launch you into space
-Monsters despawn, and vanish entirely
-Fire pits 'eat' fish
-Fire pits stop working entirely
-Other A.I Issues, Walking underwater, clipping

Personal Issues:

-Objects that you can interact with in a survival game shouldn't glow bright white from 100m away (logs, etc.)
-Beautiful map environment, but small compared to other survival games on the market

Personal verdict:

-If you have extra cash and want to support the developers, buy it
-If you want a game to play and enjoy, you need to wait, don't buy this yet, it will likely spoil the game for future enjoyment.

I’m aware it’s pre-alpha, I paid $15.00 for it, and I’m still rating it as follows
Great start, lots of potential, however, “The Forest” has plenty to finish before the general public will accept it. 2/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wont go into detail as other people have mentioned most things. The detail and graphics are really good, the only dowside is the game can lag/delay and sometimes stall. However with a little tweaking it can be very playable.

The crafting is well thought out, and along with the survival book it gives you a good idea what you can do and with what.

The locals are interesting and can flank you too, the AI is not bad. Once you get a base sorted and you've built yourself a few traps and a tree house things start to get better and you can take it a bit easier and not worry about them.

I can't wait for further improvements and I have to say this is one of the better survival games. Kind of reminds me of lost ;-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is for The Forest v0.12.
Game Grade:  A

Shorthand Review:  Survival is not easily achieved.  The Forest will put your survival skills to the test in a frist person experience you will never forget.

Detailed Review:

I personally recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a realistic survival based game.  The developers of The Forest really show true dedication to the game by their consistent efforts in updating and taking suggestions.  The Forest has different modes you can play which increase the replay value significantly.  With high graphic quality, you are really put into the action at every moment of the game.  For an in Alpha build game, the game play is shockingly smooth and highly entertaining.

To start off, I think anyone who has played around with a few early access games has been greatly disappointed with developers who just don't keep up with the game.  With The Forest, there is a very active community with truly dedicated developers.  Updates are released quite frequently ranging from once a week to once every three weeks.  In the updates, you can expect fixes to bugs and new content.  This new content always adds a whole new level of entertainment to the game.  If you feel that you are getting bored with The Forest, then just wait a week or two and you will have a blast with the newly added materials.  The developers truly lure you back into the game each update which allows you to get the most out of your money.

Anyone who has played survival games knows that the game is only as good as its replay value.  With The Forest, the replay value is very high.  One reason goes back to what I had said earlier.  The developers are always adding more content.  Not only that but you can play in two different game modes.  The first game mode involves fighting the classic and merciless cannibals which are always trying to take a bite out of you.  Messed up right?  Not as messed as their effigies but I'll keep to my word and keep specific aspects of the game a mystery (unless you have watched it on youtube).  Another way you can play is without the cannibals.  This adds more realism to the game but be aware that playing this mode may get boring after a while.  This mode can be enabled by typing veganmode in the main menu screen (there is no text box to type it in).  I would like to add that The Forest has made a multiplayer aspect to the game which can handle 8 people (recommended max).  With this said, I hope replay value won't be on your mind when you buy the game.

The last point I'm going to make about the game are the graphics.  The graphics in The Forest are outstanding.  This truly throws you into full survival mode with this addition to realism.  Don't worry however, the graphics can be lowered sufficiently to meet the needs of slower and older computers.  Laptops are even given a recommended mode so your graphics shouldn't be an issue.   Visual effects may be glitched at times, and as said before, bugs are to be expected.  The bugs will not take away from the game play and are normally fixed in the next update.

Overall, I highly recommend The Forest to anyone who enjoys survival based games.  Check out my profile for screenshots of the game.  I hope that you found this review helpful.  If you didn't, I am truly sorry that you spent your time read this.  However, I'm sure this will give you some idea of what you will see in the game.  Feedback is always wanted so if you want to know anything else or think anything should be added, just post a comment.  Again, I hope this has helped you with your decision on buying the game.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the things I truly love about this game is the atmosphere, you will see the cannibals walking around and hunting and minding their own business constantly, and it always puts me on edge. crafting takes some creativity and survival is realistic to a point I have never seen in any game (and that is coming from someone who goes camping with nothing but a knife and tent). If I can give a couple pieces of advice, craft the bow as quickly as possible, makes hunting and fighting way easier (you will still die). have no less than 3 fires and 3 effigies surrounding your camp at all times. if you encounter cannibals and you are not yet rambo, run away and hide in your cabin. if you do all of this you may survive for 3 days.

ps. I've seen aerosol cans in some of the luggage, hoping future updates allow me to pick these up and turn them into grenades, or flamethrowers.
